Then later on I found out that the coffee they serve here is Blue Bottle Coffee, and I'm pretty sure it's tastier than even Blue Bottle Coffee's own location at the Ferry Building downtown (OK, just as tasty, but the brown sugar here makes it better).

When I have coffee here I don't feel like I need to make the trip to the Castro or Mission for trendier places (the ones that take credit cards with iPads and Square, unlike here, which uses a regular terminal and charges you a 50-cent convenience fee for low-dollar credit card transactions--better a convenience fee than a hard minimum!).

The Wi-Fi is free, except during peak hours when they turn it off to keep tables free for paying customers (seating is somewhat limited, the only down side, but part of the place's charm).
author: Omar Y.

description: This place is always packed...but if you can get a table, it's a nice place to hang out, get some great coffee and even some of their food. Nice little neighborhood crowd. It's small but good place overall.
author: George M.

description:
I love love LOVE this place! It's 2 blocks from where I live and it's a really quick place to chill/get coffee/meet a friend/get work done. 
It's almost always packed with people; it's easier to find a seat for 1 then a table for 4. But if you wait 5-10 minutes usually a table clears up. 

First time I came here I got a mocha and just sat down to get some work done before I have to go home and bake my boyfriend his birthday cake. I ended up making friends with 5 people who were also there to do work on their computer. Their normal coffee for $2.50 is just a small glass of coffee, but I needed at least 2 times that for my cake. I went up to them and told them my situation and they told me I could either pay $5 for 2 glasses of coffee or pay $2.50 and they can give me the equivalent amount in one of their staff's water bottle thing but I have to promise to bring it back to them. So that's what I did. Such nice people working here!

Their Coppi (turkey, spinach, jack with cranberry jam spread, toasted) is really good!! It comes with a TON of salad with fresh berries. Soo yummy!

FREE WI-FI, good food, good coffee, good people.
author: Erica L.

description: This small cafe really took me by surprise!  My brother and I split the McAllister Scramble and the Coppi sandwich.  So good!  The scramble was a great way to start my day, and the Coppi was just full of flavor.  I'm usually hesitant to try things that mix sweet and savory tastes, but this colorful combination was just right.  Definitely out of the box, and would love to have it again next time I'm in SF.
author: Remy P.

description: Great neighborhood cafe, BUT be prepared to be kicked off their wi-fi network anytime they feel a surge in customers.  AND be prepared to pay a $.50 surcharge on any credit card charge under $10.  Business is apparently good enough to inconvenience customers - and to lose some in the process.  I purchased my next cup of coffee somewhere else.  And will do so in the future.
author: Craig M.

description: don't be fooled by their breakfast sandwich billing itself as some sort of 3x3x3" meal. It's a full on breakfast platter with some english muffin hidden somewhere inside. It's really a substantial amount of food and what initially starts as a suspiciously pricey breakfast sandwich turns in to a extremely reasonably priced plate of food.
author: Misha T.

description:
I  really can't complain about Blue Bottle Coffee, and delicious fresh food right around the corner from my apartment!  The Veggie Sandwich is a MUST try.

The vibe is very welcoming and cozy.
author: Amanda H.

description:
In my neighborhood... so that's a plus.
If you're a PB&J Fan, try the Elvis!

I am excited to try other things on the menu, including the Jack Johnson Banana Pancakes!
author: Jennie L.

description: Great, great cafe. I love the ladies that work the counter.
author: Esther C.

description:
I really really wanna love this place and I probably would if I would just stop ordering food and stick to coffee. I'm a sucker for $3 cups of coffee and they have Blue Bottle here so they pretty much have me locked down as a loyal customer. The place is just so gosh darn cute and has a great ambiance.  I've worked from here a few times but I wouldn't recommend it during peak hours. It gets really crowded, loud, and they turn off the wifi at lunch time. All their coffee drinks are great, especially the machiato. I've never been in the evening but it looks like they have great happy hour beer and wine specials. They have some cool events at night too. A few times I've walked by they had a live band playing. I;ve also seen some large groups of people sitting in a circle chatting (book club? AA meeting?) Either way they looked like they were having a good time. 

Disclaimer: My grocery store is next door to this place which is why I'm always walking by. I dont just stand outside looking in the window at night and then go home and write yelp reviews. I swear.

Unfortunately, I had to give 3 stars because of the food. I've only had breakfast items and they were all disappointing. I made a rookie mistake of ordering a breakfast burrito the first time I went. A french themed cafe can't make a good breakfast burrito? Shocking. This morning I ordered the Mr. Ventoux, which is pretty much just a normal breakfast sandwich but for some reason costs $6. The eggs were WAY overcooked and the sandwich had zero flavor. I mean its a simple breakfast sandwich. Cmon now. 

So come here for the drinks and the atmosphere. If youre hungry go grab a sandwich from Arguello market next store cause they are to die for!
author: Mary L.

description: The girls that work here are awesome! There are 4 or 5 that work the bar/register and every one of them is very friendly. Always a great environment for relaxation or busywork in Velo Rouge. Excellent breakfast as well!
author: William S.

description:
A true neighborhood cafe with a French bicycle theme, great coffee, good food, a comfortable ambiance, a long happy hour, live music in the evenings, and even good wifi!  Bienvenu chez toi!

All you could want in a local hangout!  Breakfast:  A quad latte, and maybe a bagel with cream cheese and lox.  Sunday afternoon brunch with my son:  Quad latte, hot chocolate, a hot sandwich, chocolate chip cookies, a Sunday paper and a few games of Connect Four.  Evenings:  A glass of merlot and some live music.  Perfect!

The photo doesn't show it, but they have outdoor tables along the south side, wonderful for a sunny day and only a block from the Arguello gate to Golden Gate Park!  Really, they need tables on the west side to match.  It gets crowded there at peak times!

Watch out for the no-parking zones on street-cleaning mornings.
author: Paul S.

description: They've got a super cool theme going on here. Everything's all about the bikes, some about do-it-yourself, ecoawareness, and food. There's a pump out front for you to fill up your tires and some bike racks too. Inside, there's pieces of furniture welded together from bicycle parts. They've got individual drip Blue Bottle coffee here, but only the Chiapas roast, I think. There's only 3 drippers on the drip bar, so hang tight if there's a line. Service is great. Restroom is available. Wireless internet is free. Accepts cash only if under limit. Close to Golden Gate Park.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Another nice little cafe located in the lone mountain/pan handle area.  They offer a nice Sunday brunch with a trendy atmosphere.  They also have happy hour wine specials.  Overall a good alternative to your everyday franchisee.
author: Andrew M.

description: Best breakfast burrito I've ever had. Place is small though and usually crowded -- so be prepared to get aggressive to snag a table or chair.
author: Zach M.

description: Really cool atmosphere, great coffee, good food. Whole place is bicycle themed.
author: Maxim L.

description: Yet one more stellar review for this awesome neighborhood gem. Coffee, great. Breakfast and lunch food, great. Atmosphere with outdoor seating, great. So what more can one say, this place is great.
author: C F.

description:
Espresso To Go is under normal circumstances the norm wouldn't everybody agree but not @ Velo Rouge, I went in there the other day and asked for a double espresso to go, but was told straight up by the coffee clerk that we don't do that! The explanation was mind boggling, they are to small To Go I was told so we don't offer that 'service'. Maybe because they had too many accidents with patrons on red bicycles (Velo Rouge) with espresso in hand....ohhh I don't know but logic has certainly gone out the window.

Zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz

PS by the way, you can get everything else To Go there.....
author: Steiner A.

description: A truly unique cafe, with excellent food, Blue Bottle coffee, and beer and wine. It's a lovely stop to or from Golden Gate Park, which is only a block away. The inside is full of vintage French bicycle advertisements, old photos, and furniture created from repurposed bicycles.
author: Jeff F.

description: Cute, quaint, and delicious. Fantastic Blue Bottle Coffee. $1 refills on coffee. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer C.

description: they have a bathroom!; oatmeal with fruit was not sophisticated, but generous
author: Karl L.

description:
DRINK:
Chai latte = yummieee!


SERVICE:
Great & friendly :) free wifi


ATMSPHERE:
It's cute, it's got character, got the bike theme going, only one outlet in the middle, nice ambiance & popular lil cafe for a Monday noontime, few ppl on laptops, keyless single bathroom 1024
author: Angela L.

description:
I would have never known about the Velo Rouge Cafe had it not been for a One Brick volunteer who suggested our group go there for brunch following an early morning volunteer project at the nearby St. John's Presbyterian Church.

I've come out of Golden Gate Park and onto Arguello Blvd. countless times without even noticing the existence of this little cafe.  Inside is a charming little space with black metal tables and chairs, books and games for patrons to enjoy, a little glass cabinet with fresh baked goods and a menu quite more extensive than is shown on the MenuPages page that the Yelp link connects to.

It was freezing cold this morning, and not even the six block walk from the church to the cafe was enough to warm myself, but a freshly brewed hot cocoa with a frothy topping of sweet whipped cream was just what this non-coffee drinker needed to warm up.

I love how the cafe staff allows their patrons to move around the furniture inside to form bigger group sitting areas as we were one of two fairly large groups enjoying the cafe this morning.

From their brunch menu I ordered the French Toast.  My only regret was not having a camera to record this beautifully presented, delectable treat.  The French Toast is three slices of a thick, coarse bread (baked fresh by Tartine according to the cafe's menu description) that is battered and grilled in a egg-heavy coating on one side only.  Its final presentation is dusted with powdered sugar and fresh fruit slices of bananas and persimmons.  A cup of warmed syrup comes with it too.  The sugars from my brunch selection and my beverage were just what I needed to kick start the rest of my day.

It seemed like they have quite a large staff for a small cafe.  The service is excellent with friendly, smiling faces all around.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Great food!! My boyfriend and I roadtripped to San Fran and stopped in this cafe along the park. Great atmosphere, really friendly staff who were more than happy to recommend a few choices. 

We ordered the BALT - bacon, lettuce, tomato, avocado sandwich- it was heavenly!! And the breakfast burrito with bacon was equally as delicious! 

We consider ourselves to have high standards for food, and to make us want to leave a review really means it was good! Definitely coming back next time we are in the city and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!! :))
author: Cami C.

description: I was looking for an affordable place to have some coffee and a good breakfast. I found this place on yelp and since I'm an avid yelp-er, I decided to give this place a visit.   Yelp is like my best friend when I'm looking for some good places to eat and this is one of them I recommend you come and visit there's all kinds of things that you would enjoy on the menu. It's simple yet nicely prepared and tastes delicious   thank you Velo Rouge cafe.
author: AnA Avatar Z.

description: Great location! Good neighborhood cafe. Nice breezy corner steps away from GG park. Tables outside great for sunny day or to watch the fog roll into the inner Richmond !
author: Molly S.

description: I had the Mcallister scramble and it was delicious! I greatly recommend this location and specifically this dish.
author: Indira S.

description:
My first visit to Velo Rouge had nothing to do with coffee.

Cutie was trying to feed me some fantastic homemade dim sum while I was driving. As we rounded the corner onto Arguello, I bit her finger. Hard. The agonizing shriek preceded an "OMG! What have I done?" guilt mirroring a pain that required immediate relief. I stopped in front of Velo Rouge, hit the flashers and darted in with my empty wallet, begging for a small cup of ice. The kind lady behind the counter rushed into action, bagging an impromptu ice pack to alleviate the pain. 

I did not taste the coffee that day, but I have visited on many very pleasant occasions thereafter. The tree-lined setting is a nice place to sit down with a coffee or beer, relax or watch the World Cup or Tour de France. Every time I visit, I can feel the love..and the relief of that first visit.
author: Andy R.

description: Was looking for free wifi and this place was nearby so just walked in and got a latte.  A small cup of latte rang up at $4.62.  Wtf??? I am NOT at a cafe on champs-élysées!!! An 8oz cup of ordinary latte should not cost 5 bucks.  I did get my work done though so I guess it was worth it.
author: Swati K.

description:
Cute place I yelped while at St. Mary's and in need of some good coffee close by!  Cafe latte was very rich and smooth, their McAllister Scramble breakfast sandwich was good too.   I realized why they named it McAllister as I sat staring outside and saw the street sign, they're on McAllister/Arguello!  (My DUH moment!  Hey, I'm not from this area even though it's been my home-away-from-home for the past month!)

I actually came back the next morning and ordered a macchiato - totally not a Starbuck's macchiato I've been accustomed to which has caramel!  I learned what a true macchiato was and ended up ordering another latte after downing that shot of espresso/cream.
author: Gigi M.

description:
Velo is a great spot for locals and tourists alike. All the employees are certified by Blue Bottle Coffee so they know their stuff- try the Lone Mountain for a strong kickstart to your morning. On those morning where you just want the perfect scramble, or a delish pastry, or maybe you need to get rid of that lingering headache....opt for the breakfast burrito- best in town! Mac and the whole velo team are also the most inviting, helpful, and all around best people to get your food/caffeine fix from. Highly Recommend!

Pizza's at night around the weekends- great for families

$3 pilsner and ranger on tap for happy hour- and they're always happy over there

Classic SF spot for bikers and GGpark goers

Support your local businesses!
author: Anna C.

description:
I go to school a few blocks up the hill from here and it was convenient and easy to get to--especially when almost nothing is open at 9:30pm especially around campus. A few friends and I came here just looking for a place to chill and talk over some coffee one night. 

Overall, I really enjoyed my experience here. The worker was very friendly although closing time was so near and a pack of college students roll in. The pastries were delicious and the drinks were good too. However, I really wish we had come earlier so I could try the great sandwiches I've heard so much about. After creating such a fuss for the worker, I decided to put the tables back to where they were before we attacked the place and clean up all of our trash and gathered our cups for her. It was a nice atmosphere here, I will definitely come back another day!
author: Sheri N.

description:
This cafe is too cute. Tucked in a corner in the Richmond district, it's frequented by an interesting mix of locals. I ordered the Coppi panini (turkey, spinach, jack with a jam spread) with a side of salad, which was so good! The portion was perfect, and it wasn't sloppily made. We did have to wait a while for the food, but it was worth it. 

Love the atmosphere of this place, with the personable staff and cozy couches. It does get kind of stuffy because it has little tables that are right next to the line for ordering food. Other than that, I have no complaints! Oh and I also heard good things about their Blue Bottle coffee, although my friend said hers was lukewarm when it was brought out, so maybe ask for the coffee to be extra hot. =)
author: Christine A.

description: One of my favorite cafes.  Busy on weekend mornings so I tend to avoid it but otherwise great drink and food, and a good space for reading or working.
author: Tim A.

description:
Ah, my beloved Velo Rouge... I feel bad doing this to you, but you (actually, your management) need some tough lovin'. Or some suggestions, to be exact.

Inner Richmond, surprisingly, does not have much in terms of coffee shops. They are far and few between, and walk more than 2 blocks away from Clement street, and you are in a caffeine-free, java-depleted zone. But then there's Velo Rouge, an oasis of a cafe in the hitherland of toddler-strallers, golden retrievers and your friendly unemployed wanna-be writers. 

It's actually the last category that I have my beef with when it comes to Velo Rouge. The category also knowns as "Free-wi-fi-loaders" or "table hoggers". Here's the sitch. You come into Velo Rouge to have some of their excellent Blue Bottle coffee and one of their delicious breakfasts, but oh, ah, where do you intend to eat it? For all of their 4 tables are typically and firmly occupied, often by just one person and their laptop. 

I mean, I realize a free Wi-Fi is a nice perk and it probably helps fill the cafe up in less-popular hours, but on a weekend, at breakfast or brunch time, I think it's time to either get rid of the freeloaders who nurse their coffees or just bring in more tables. Perhaps, smaller size? Or turn off the Wi-Fi on Saturdays and Sundays?

But perhaps I am not being fair to Velo Rouge. Its owners and staff do seem to work hard and are generally nice people. I am sure they don't want to discourage their regulars, and the place IS tiny. It's just frustrating is all, when you literally have to fight over the next free table with a pregnant lady and her menacing-looking Boston terrier.
author: Evg R.

description: Love Velo Rouge.  Great breakfast, Blue Bottle Coffee and an awesome happy hour!
author: Carl P.

description: great salad, good coffee, BUT THE DOOR! If you want to sit inside and hear the door slam constantly then great but maybe they could put a sign up or a door stop.
author: Lindsay B.

description: I love the blue bottle coffee and the breakfast burrito.  Best in the city!  The place can be very crowded on the weekends, so best to wake up early.
author: carolyne c.

description:
Alright here's the deal.  So I was a frequent customer here for about 2 years only because I lived up the street.  Mind you, awesome location and what not and Blue Bottle, gotta love it.

The set backs...
1)  SNOBBY, I'm not just saying that to be an a**hole.  Truly and utterly SNOBBY.  The staff, never genuine and caught up in whatever was going wrong in their lives.  For some reason this "cafe" has everyone aiming their noses so high up their a** they lose the common courtesy of  "pardon me, excuse me, or I'm sorry" for bumping into you.  Which made me start getting my coffee next door at Arguello Market.  (There are a few nice customers that go there, but don't bet your dollar, it's playing roulette)

2)  Customer Service from a scale of 1-5  you get a big fat ZERO.  I've encountered more than 5 times where I was clearly next in line yet the "young blonde" gets to order first.  NEGATIVE!

3)  Pastry Case...I wouldn't touch it, looks unsanitary and isn't even "fluffed" or maintained throughout the day.

Sorry Velo Rouge you are NOT the business.
author: Edrian D.

description: This is a great cafe for neighborhood locals. The grub is tasty (from sammies to savory pies to breakfast croissants), the coffee is good, and they have nice happy hour specials on wine and beer. The happy hours start early and the staff will even start them earlier, if you ask nicely. :)
author: Nami S.

description: I absolutely love this coffee shop ! I have been going here for many many years ! Love there coffee , it's made to order ! Drip coffee is so delicious !
author: Prayank J.

description:
Went  back this evening for my caffeine fix. 

Still haven't tried the Blue Bottle coffee, but opted for their latte instead. The only flavor syrup they had was vanilla (which was what I wanted :]). The latte was very smooth and so far, is keeping me up and running. 

The downside is is that it was $4.00... kinda harsh on a student's wallet, but the latte was good and made with love.

:D
author: Angela A.

description: This is my local coffee house. I love that it's there!  In fact it's the reason my hood is so popular!  Great staff!  Great coffee!  Great ambiance!  Sadly the food is just ok. While it's crafted well and tastes good I'm just a bit bored with it.  Also, I'm not crazy about fruit in my salad. In the past they used to host guest chefs in the evenings from around the Bay Area. I wish they would do that again.  If it's a sunny or foggy day in the Richmond I would still recommend this place!!!  :-)
author: P M.

description:
They have somehow found the brilliant yet hard-to-achieve balance between quality, fresh-tasting food and great service with a casual atmosphere and commitment to sustainability. They make it seem so easy that all these things fall naturally into place, and the cafe is obviously the love-child of people who care about their customers, the food they serve, and the mark they leave on a community.

FANTASTIC menu with all your caffeinated preferences and Blue Bottle Coffee. DELICIOUS baked goods. Soup daily. Sandwiches in huge proportions. Everyone must try their pauper pies-- warm and hearty. I am confident in saying everything on the menu will be tasty, substantial but not heavy, and will come out of the kitchen quickly.

AND they're not after your wallet! Dream cafe, is that you?

Bicycle-themed ambiance is really cute, um, as are the guys working there.
author: Jen N.

description: This place has pretty legit breakfast and their coffee/chai tea is really yummy. They even give you an extra shot glass of chai since the mug is too small for the portions they provide. The location is cute and it's walking distance to Golden Gate Park and the Conservatory. Good service too :)
author: Marie S.

description: Great local place in Inner Richmond. Funky little cafe, friendly staff and locals chatting away. Very good coffee and food. A great place to while away a sunny San Fran morning.
author: Mike J.

description: delicious food, comfy ambiance, sweet people... pretty much everything you could possibly want in a neighborhood cafe. their banana pancakes are to die for... really you can't go wrong!
author: Barbara S.

description:
People here are friendly, the salads and peasant pies are all I've had to eat but they are delicious! I also really like their coffee and the fact that they have some outdoor seating for when its nice out.

Their decor and music is fun, and they have free wifi. This is all around a solid spot, although I do wish that they could have more ventilation because when its warm out the sun comes directly in and it gets pretty hot!

They also have a decent happy hour with a few good beers on tap.
author: Annah D.

description:
Wife and I stopped in after tromping around Golden Gate Park for a few hours. She had scrambled eggs and stuff - which was good. They were scrambled eggs.

I had the "Coppi" - a turkey sandwich with some cheese, spinach, and a jam spread. It was really tasty.

A pleasant way to break up our walk.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I love the Velo Rouge! 

Since it opened it's been a great place! 

The coffee is tasty. The food is delicious (might be my favorite salads in town and definitely my favorite soups). 

I like the evening music and the community vibe. 
Thanks Velo Rouge owners and staff for being outstanding!! 

This is the BEST cafe in San Francisco
author: eliote D.

description:
Stopped by Velo Rouge on a whim to have brunch with my sister, and while the food was good, it wasn't all that memorable. What I do remember about the place is the oh so friendly staff, who were helpful with the menu, even though the place was literally bursting at the seams with people. Our order was originally to go because there was no seats in sight, but a table opened up midway, and the cashier changed our order with no complaints. The environment was comfortable, and definitely had a handful of regulars, who chatted it up with the folks behind the counter. Also, they have a few outside tables, which I imagine would be nice on a sunny day.

All in all, I wont be rushing to head back to Velo Rouge, but if Im in the area, I wouldnt mind eating there again.
author: David M.

description: Would give 6 stars, for everything from the staff to the coffee to the food to the decor and neighborhood and location and everything, but sometimes I can't find a place to sit down, it's just that desirable of a place to be. I wish I could suggest a solution instead of merely pointing out a problem, but there's not really a way to put more tables in there, and the reason it's packed is because the place is awesome anyway.
author: Eric S.

description: I have been to Velo Rouge the last 3 times I've visited S.F.! Loved the vibe, the neighborhood, the food, ambiance, live entertainment and friendly customer service! Will always stop by when I head North!
author: Marie H.

description: We love Velo Rouge! We are from LA and come whenever we visit our daughters who live nearby. The food and coffee are great. Everyone has always been really friendly to us.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
It's my neighborhood spot. It's seriously 2 blocks from my apartment. It's a nice place to go chill at.

I've been for breakfast and lunch. 
The coffee is really good but I was wondering why it's a little bit more pricier than Starbucks, it's because it's Blue Bottle. So good. 

The Mount Venteux is delish!
Bfriend has gotten the Breakfast Burrito more than once. 

Love the bike theme. =)
author: Melissa T.

description: The breakfast burrito and hot chocolate are heavenly! Love this cafe from the outdoor seating, the staff (shout out to Manny!), food, coffee, and people that go there.  I am so lucky to live so close.
author: Molica A.

description:
After reading the Yelp reviews for this place, I was super excited to try it. Everything about it sounded cute: the menu, the decor, etc. I decided I'd have my post-half marathon breakfast here! 

But something was off. Maybe it was the fact that it was 8:30am on a Sunday. The dude who took my order was most certainly high. I asked him what was in the vegetarian sandwich on the menu (a daily special which said it was made with fresh/seasonal vegetables). Reallly slowly, he starts listing "Uhh... cucumbers..? ... lettuce..." I replied "I'll have the banana pancakes". 

The banana pancakes weren't good, though. And the bananas came on top! Not cooked inside :(  And the chocolate croissant my friend ordered wasn't even heated up. And some dude sitting by himself at the table next to us was staring at me, and also did not appear to be doing anything else (not even eating). But I suppose that's not Velo Rouge's fault.

I almost want to give this place an extra star because the whole experience was pretty comical and I had a great time regardless, but seriously, don't go here.
author: Richa A.

description:
Really good sandwiches and similar.  Generous portions.  Spetacular salads (fresh strawberries or melon on the salads right now).  Friendly staff.

BTW, if there are not tables available (a frequent occurance) you can ask someone to share.
author: Josh B.

description: Weak coffee and expensive.  Sandwich was greasy and gross - don't think cream cheese should be served hot.  Salad too salty.
author: Dora V.

description: Love this place!  Great vibe and equally great food.  Beer, wine, coffee... you name it.   Check it out!
author: Dan R.

description:
Mmmmmm latte sans vanilla = good. 

Seating? Tricky to find... but... that's a good sign. ;-) 

Oh and the pizza? I didnt have any, but WHOA it looked and SMELLED AMAZING! Had I not already had dinner plans, I would have DEFINITELY grabbed a pizza here... next time I'm in Inner Richmond, I know where to go!
author: Jodie B.

description: I don't even live in this neighborhood, but I make the short trek here almost every weekend to have their vanilla latte and Ventoux breakfast sandwich. The BALT is another winner.
author: Dan B.

description: Love this place.  Very good latte or Cappo.  Breakfast croissant sandwich is amazing.  Pleasant music at a very appropriate volume.  I wish I had discovered this place sooner.  Parking has been easy as well.
author: Gary S.

description: Gets it done. Nice place to program, while waiting for a date or otherwise. Good banana bread. Convenient and nice vibe.
author: Tom H.

description:
After about four years of meaning to go here, I finally stopped by for the first time today. I got there around 5pm so I could read for a bit, then listen to the live music promised on their website every Friday starting at 7. 

I started off with a macchiato for $3.25 (it wasn't very good-- room temperature, weird aftertaste). I then delved into Anna Karenina for the next hour and decided to grab a snack and another drink while waiting for the music. I got a slice of yummy banana bread for $1.75 (moist and plenty of walnuts) and a pint of Flat Tire for the special price of $3. While paying for it, I asked the cashier if there was going to be music. To my disappointment, he said that they changed their music schedule to every other Saturday. I wish they would've changed the info on their website too.

Well, seeing as I was there anyway, I decided to stay and take my time. 

Price: Pricey, but fairly typical for SF cafes.

Ambience: Small but clean; cute bike theme with ample seating (some even cleverly made of bike parts); charmingly scuffed floors

Vibe: Very low-key and casual, plenty of locals: students, young couples, chatting friends, mothers and their children

Service: Friendly (I was reading by the window with the blinds pulled down and an employee came over to pull it up so that I could have more lighting); I ended up staying about an hour and a half without feeling rushed out.

Verdict: I won't go out of my way to frequent this place, but I wouldn't mind stopping in now and again for a cheap pint and a relaxing place to read.
author: Teresa G.

description: Beer & coffee. Awesome. We went in here for a drink before dinner. I had a SF steamer and a shot of espresso. I love the atmosphere, and the fact that they have both alcohol and coffee. Very cute, trendy spot. Fair prices, too. I have a feeling that if I lived in SF, I would be spending more time here.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Not much to it beyond location. Food is just ok. Service not great. I used to stop in there when in the area, and more often played the Free Range Fridays folk music series and the huge, annual Hardly Strictly parties. But the owner of this lucky little hole in the wall has bitten the hand that fed and unceremoniously booted out the lovely couple that brought them SO much business since 2005 over the flimsiest of excuses: a minor disagreement over beverages for performers. This truly sucks. I'm not going back and I won't recommend anyone else does either. No big deal. I never would have gone without Free Range Fridays in the first place.
author: MW T.

description: This place is a short walk from my apartment, and Velo Rouge never disappoints.  Whether I'm in the mood for breakfast, lunch or even wine i can always count on this little gem.  Consistently the best latte I've had in SF (made with blue bottle coffee).  The customer service is really good too.  Even though its counter service, I always feel welcomed and inclined to tip.  Seating is limited and to the best of my knowledge they don't have a bathroom.
author: Angelica  C.

description:
I'd give this place 2-3 stars. The food is great but the pretense makes me gag. I find the staff to be in that category as well.

Yes, they have Blue Bottle but I don't care for this cafe's method of making it. They don't spend a lot time pouring in increments and it can turn out weak. 

Forget about the weekend, it's a see and be seen place. I guess it's just not my scene.

I do love the bicycle parking out front though!
author: Dianne N.

description:
Awesome place!

DRINK:
Chai latte = yummieee!

SERVICE:
Great & friendly :) free wifi

ATMSPHERE:
It's cute, it's got character, got the bike theme going, only one outlet in the middle, nice ambiance & popular lil cafe for a Monday noontime, few ppl on laptops, keyless single bathroom 1024
Really good coffee, really good food. Awesome neighborhood cafe with a great sense of community. It's busy for a reason!
author: Andrew S.

description:
A true Richmond District gem. This joint is especially great on a sunny day.  They've got a few tables outside and it's right next to the Park. 

The sandwich/salad combo is one of the best deals in the city-delicious and BIG portions. My tapeworm was not disappointed ;)

Their desserts and pastries are tasty too. The staff is always affable and I recommend you check it out, even on a rainy day (plenty of indoor seating and they've got a slough of board games and magazines for ya). 

Bonus*  If you're a cyclist you'll really feel like you fit in. Wait til you see the décor and you'll mean what I know.  

** Apropos sign next to the paper towel dispenser in the bano; pants dry, trees die. Clever!  To prove their integrity they have easy to use recycle and compost bins in the restaurant.

Ride your bike there today!
author: Alan S.

description:
A coffee-breakfast-pizza-beer-wine-music hangout with Eco-cred and Euro-pretensions may be a common enough sight in the Mission, but the fact that the Inner Richmond now has one makes me very happy for the Westside (and jealous that they didn't choose the Inner Sunset...but I'm not above sneaking across the park).

Due to the tiny space, the crowds can be spilling out onto the sidewalk when there's good music (like the sea shanty night featuring The Barbary Ghosts, what up!) but I've been able to wander in both on weeknights and weekend mornings (pre-11) and grab a table straight away.  As for food, the petite lattes are superb, wines are delicious, they have fat tire on tap, breakfasts are modest but high-quality, and the pizzas (Wednesday and Friday), while limp in the crust, are sizable and creative (olives and feta on Hawaiian = genius!).  In short, I can only hope this is the first salvo in a long wave of Westside Velo-fication.
author: Wes M.

description:
Very cute, and pleasant. Love that there's plenty of free parking on the street, and how we could see Golden Gate Park! If we'd wanted to walk to the Park from there, we could have. Decent neighborhood.

The seating is really good and so is the service. Really laid-back, happy atmosphere. Didn't eat, only had coffee. They take credit cards. Would definitely go back.
author: Sue Ellen E.

description:
Great neighborhood cafe with charming decor. Velo Rouge has consistently GOOD food, good music, and really good (Blue Bottle) coffee. The food might seem slightly overpriced until you receive your order and realize the portions are actually huge. I keep coming back for their paninis and what is possibly my favorite salad in the city (such good fruit! who knew?) VR also has a fine tea selection and your basic cafe breakfast needs. Great vibes, free wi-fi, and all-around lovely spot.

Of course - if you're in a hurry, this probably isn't the place to get your morning cup. Otherwise, a recommended lazy day spot (and a great place to bring friends and out-of-town visitors).
author: Sam S.

description:
Bonjour mes amis!!  

Ok that's about all the Francais you'll have to deal with a Velo!  Fairly small place (but has outdoor seating) packs a wonderful interesting ambiance, with such an awesome set of people working (owners?) there.  

Anything you order on the menu, you'll end up loving.  Really fresh ingredients, mixing up brunch, sandwiches, breakfast burritos (yum), salads, and great coffee (blue bottle yum) drinks.  

They sorta have internet, but turn it off at times during peak hours.  This seems annoying to me as I don't see the point in doing that to valued / repeat customers.

Also agree with Sheldon, the coffee cups are kinda small when I have to take a bit off to put some creme, yet pay $2 (it was $2.50 before).
author: Mark K.

description:
Good food for breakfast/brunch/lunch, nothing that jumps out.  Very friendly staff but they seem to be unorganized.  Instead of divide and conquer, they have 2-3 people all scrambling to clean dishes, make coffee and take cash at the same time.  That makes service slow a lot of times.

They have different board games including backgammon and lots of magazines mostly related to biking.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I like bikes. My friend likes cute little cafes.  Velo Rouge Cafe is a winning combo.

We stopped here to get our grub before hitting up golden gate park to go skate.  
I liked the vibe of this place. We got lucky and got a table, so we occupied our time by playing one of the many board games that they had.  

My breakfast burrito was pretty good, and the coffee was good. 

Nice little neighborhood vibe.  They also are very bike friendly, and if you need to buy a bike tube or something, they have them there too.

I'd come here again if I lived near here.
author: Richard D.

description:
Went twice last week - once for work and once for breakfast. Finding a table was a bit of a chore, but nothing a little scowling couldn't fix. I ordered a breakfast sandwich which was a bit pricey, but still enjoyable. The coffee was quite good. It's some sort of special blend invented by the Shah of Iran in 1200 AD (might wanna double check that). I'll def go back. Probably today. 

Also, there's a hot girl who works the register.
author: Aaron Z.

description: A sweet cozy French Cafe with a bicycle twist :-) I stopped here for brunch after a run in golden gate park. All the food was fresh and nice quality. The portions were pretty large so my finance and I split the McAllister Scramble and ordered some really nice chi. The entire staff is very courteous and you may get to sit at the funky corner table and chairs made from a bike pieces! Nice place to stop by for an inexpensive but enjoyable meal.
author: Megha V.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop. The cappuccinos are great and the staff is friendly. It is bike themed which is really cute. The only downside is that it is small and tends to get packed especially on the weekends. Sometimes this doesn't make for the most ideal brunch but I still love it. It has character and is obviously well loved in the community.
author: Brittany N.

description:
Short and sweet: 

Coffee was great, food was blah. I could have made it better at home. The McAllister Omelet was seriously lacking in flavor and style.

Skip the grub, just grab the java.
author: Sharonrose B.

description:
Velo Rouge (French for "red bicycle") is a perfect breakfast/lunch/brunch spot for anyone looking for a casual sidewalk cafe with excellent food.  Situated on Arguello, one block from Fulton, it's a great place to hit up before you head into Golden Gate Park.

Everything I've had there has been excellent, but my most ringing endorsement has to go to the McAlister Scramble breakfast sandwich.  It's absolutely stellar on it's own, but if you want to spice it up, add some of the Pico Pica sauce from the shelf over by the coffee station.
author: Matt V.

description: Great neighborhood gem.  Fast service, blue bottle coffee and friendly staff.
author: D M.

description: Sweet little bike themed cafe, amazing coffee (blue bottle?) and friendly people. Had the mt. Ventoux croissant breakfast sandwich with avocado-to die for! Blue bottle coffee, little wine and beer list, fantastically different tea options... the ONLY downside to this place is how busy it always is... i feel like I'm hoarding tables, or hovering over people!
author: Kira M.

description:
There's definitely a sense of (biking) community here.  I hear the food is pretty good, and the occasional live band playing is fun too, though I have yet to experience those things for myself.  The Blue Bottle coffee, is of course, amazing.

When there's time, it's definitely worth the quick jaunt to Velo Rouge over most other Inner Richmond Cafes.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Cute little cafe place to hang out on a sunny day. Their sandwiches are good and their South African savory pies even better. They serve beer too!

Very pleasant and relaxed atmosphere with a good selection of up to date magazines to peruse. Their hours are a bit spotty though.
author: Helena H.

description:
This is my favorite cafe in San Francisco. Great coffee, comfort food, and some of the nicest folks around work here. As a local to the neighborhood I've been coming here for years, and they never dissapoint. Perfect spot to grab breakfast or a pint and pizza in the evenings. Such a great value for what you recieve! 

Don't come here in a rush. It's not starbucks and they don't push a button to make your drinks. There is also often a line. But well worth the wait if you can just be patient :)
author: Anna H.

description: This place is a charming spot to take a break and cheer up your day.  If it gets too crowded with people working on their laptops they'll cut off the internet. It's a small place and this allows everyone to sit down for food/drinks. My coffee was gorgeous almost too pretty to drink. I didn't try the food, but I'm sure it's worth it. :D So happy to have moved into the area right down the street from this gem. Rumor has it that they are open till 10pm and I'm sure I'll be back soon!
author: Heather J.

description:
Great little cafe.
And when I say "little" I mean it. The tables are almost always all full- but that should tell you something. 
Well, it tells you 2 things: 1) they need more space  2) this place is worth being at.
The coffee is good, but the latte is where it's at. DeFreakingLicious.
The food is tasty (if you can get a table to eat it at)
Outside tables are great for sunny afternoon beers and everybody who works there is super friendly.

I don't suggest making a special trip for this joint, but if you live in the neighborhood or happen to be in the park or something it's totally worth stopping in.
author: Valerie G.

description: Excellent service, great atmosphere and the food was healthy and tasty! Highly recommend!!!! Sat outside in the sun and had a wonderful time.
author: Kimberly R.

description:
First things first: DELICIOUS BREAKFAST BURRITOS!!!

This place is cute, friendly and serves up some scrumptious breakfast. The people inside seemed to be a mixed crowd, sort of like the Richmond itself. The staff is friendly, and I've even called in an order before and it was ready to go and exactly what I ordered when I picked it up. 

I love going here on a Saturday morning to eat me some breakfast burritos and drink some Blue Bottle. Definitely recommend here! But don't bring too many people, it's pretty small.
author: Brianne H.

description:
Gf and I stumbled upon this place on a beautiful Sunday afternoon.  You can't go wrong with Blue Bottle coffee.  Menu selection is limited (standard breakfast fare for a coffe shop), but the food was fresh.

They managed to capture that elusive "coffee shop" vibe.
author: Mike B.

description:
Two thumbs up!!  

Had the McAllister Scramble... and it was amazing!  THe Latte was beyond words... and I should know since I'm a huge coffee snob.... so trust me it's good stuff!

Honestly, I am trying to find an excuse to come to SF just so I can eat there again!

it's located at the corner with plenty of places to park on the street!  Oh man... i need to come back soon!  

Having withdrawals already!
author: Jo T.

description:
Velo Rouge is the charming corner cafe/coffee shop I've been dreaming of all my life. Blue Bottle, great food items, beer on tap (and a happy hour!), and some live music as well! 

There's always people going in/out, so I wouldn't call it a great study spot (unless you don't mind the noise and people). It does make a great spot for catching with an old friend - or getting to know a new one. ;) 

It's just a block away from GG Park...and just around the corner from me!
author: Kanara T.

description: What a great find! Super nice people, delicious coffee, outside tables, cool decor, clean bathroom, food looks great but didn't try it. Good date spot, bike friendly, a little crowded on a spring Saturday at noon but not too bad.
author: Ernie H.

description:
I stop by here every morning my coffee maker doesn't get turned on. The Blue Bottle Coffee is individually dripped per cup. Exquisite! My only complaint is that they sometimes use a french press to speed things up. This would be fine with me if it was strained a bit better. I really don't like grounds floating on top. However they will always drip a cup if you ask. Blue Bottle lattes and caps are the best I've had.  

The food is always yummy. However, I do sometimes have to give it an extra shake of salt. I love bits of fruit in the salads they serve along side the sandwiches.  

The best thing about Velo is the atmosphere. It is always buzzing with great people from the people in the kitchen to the people sitting on the sidewalk.  This is a fantastic spot to get some work done or play a game of Connect Four! (yes they have games.... how cool is that?) 

For the dog owners this is great spot to stop on your morning walk. Outside there is a water dish for the thirsty pups and a row of bistro tables that are perfect on sunny day. 

Velo Rouge Cafe is one of the most valuable parts of this neighborhood.
author: Erin M.

description: Love this place. Yelped it and saw the high reviews, so my boyfriend and I decided to try it out. Little behold this little place surprised us. Walked in and the place was filled. the portions are filling and tasty as well. I love their delicious hot chocolate. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants some good food. :)
author: Jessica T.

description:
Had the Pantani. It was delicious. Comes with a great salad. You could easily split this with a friend. I had to take half home and then I of course forgot it was in my backpack. Waste of a killer sandwich.
Staff is friendly too.
author: Christy F.

description: Friendly staff, well made and great coffee. Nice theme to the decor too.
author: Hugo B.

description: After a nice walk in the park and chilling at the Conservatory of Flowers, the lady and I decided to walk somewhere for food.  The closest place was a cute looking coffee shop that charged me $12 for a couple eggs and strips of bacon.  It would have been delicious for half the cost, but damn.  I was too hungry to go somewhere else, so I grinned and bore it.
author: David B.

description:
After a royally crappy day at work today, who knew that a visit to the cafe across the street from my apartment could completely change my mood? My book proposal's due tomorrow, and I realized that I probably won't last through the night without the help of some Blue Bottle, so I hurried over to Velo Rouge 15 minutes before closing time (10PM).

Of course, they were closing shop, and I felt like a douche for even trying to order at the last minute. But the barrista understood I was desperate because I was about to pull an all-nighter, so she dripped me a cup of coffee on the spot. She had already shut down the register, so she gave it to me for free -- AND she offered me a free pastry (or two, or three) because they were all about to be thrown out anyway. I've been coming here two years, but now I'm certain this is the best cafe in San Francisco.

I'm pumped and dead set on finishing this book proposal by tomorrow. Thanks, Velo Rouge.
author: Brian C.

description:
3.5 stars.  I like the coffee dudes.  They were very friendly, all 3 of them.  One went as far as to get me a lid for my coffee.  Awhhh.  I felt "special".  Didn't try any of the food but I was in need of a caffeine fix mid-day.  They make a better cup of Blue Bottle coffee than the BB coffee shop in the Ferry Building, if you ask me.  They decorate the foam which is wasted because it gets covered up by a lid unless you're dining in.  The latte was bold and hands down much better than coffee at Tully's but steep for $3.50.  The mocha is pricier at $3.95.  The mocha wasn't too sweet but sort of chalky tasting.  
They have a coffee card, buy 10 coffees get one free, but one stamp per person per visit.   Not sure I'd be back for another cup of coffee because I think Starbucks is more reasonable cost-wise, but would consider trying the food another time.
author: Ry T.

description:
Good place to get stuff done. Free wifi, they have counter space with bar stools within close reach of the outlet. Seems like there is reasonable parking available in the early afternoons, mostly 2hr spots, as i'm typing this review, i am actually exceeding my 2 hr parking limit as we speak. i like living on the edge, its my dangerous lifestyle. But i fully intend on dashing to my car at the first sight of the DPT!!!!

Cute surroundings, charming, clean, with a cute open/close sign made out of beans and my small vanilla latte, although it cost me $4, it was filled to the brim in an ikea cup with a elegant leaf design. service here is pretty good. Lots of regulars, and large windows for people and dog watching (today i got an added bonus of witnessing a fender bender right in front of the cafe!). Couple of chairs and tables outside, for a nice day (not right now tho, its freaking FOGGY outside). 

They serve a variety of plates, i see a lot of people having salads and what looks like a small pot pie looking-ish thing on the side. They also offer CRUNCHIE bars and  TOFFIE CRISPS! which is rare b/c i only see those candy bars when i'm in Canada, or at cost plus world market .

This place has gained my full appreciation for a wifi stop if needed in this neck of the woods. Not here often, but if i am, i'm coming here for sure.
author: Irene C.

description:
Call it mystery, nostalgia, or even velophiles stop before or after a ride, but there is something about going to a place that has a free bike pump (outside to use) and a beautiful red bike hanging in the doorway. Even more enticing is the wait you'll commonly find on Sunday morning as everyone enjoys this beautiful space before heading off to GG park for a spin or their usual Sunday adventures.

Carrying Blue Bottle Coffee Co. and having amazing meals of all kind including the Mt. Ventoux egg sandwich or a simple granola garnished with the best of fruits (+ yogurt or milk), Velo Rouge blends European sensibility with the concept of SF district culture. This is a space that can easily function as a morning, afternoon or night to eat out with your taste palette never left behind. Socially, it's also functions as a great spot to meet the neighbors.

Be sure to pick up a carabiner clip travel coffee mug if you go... magic can happen when on the cycling on the road and you don't want to go thirsty.
author: Mario G.

description:
I've ridden by this place a hundred times. Finally, I was walking through the neighborhood, hungry, and thought I'd grab a quick sandwich.  Whoa.

When I ordered, I thought I was over-paying for a sandwich. When it arrived, I realized I was underpaying for culinary artistry and an impressive meal.

The sandwich had more meat than I really needed, and was delicious, but what really impressed me was the unexpected salad. Unexpected, and the best part was that it included a wider variety of healthy ingredients than I've had in a small shop like this in quite awhile.  It actually contained ingredients that I really need in my diet, but because I eat out too much, don't get enough of.  

Delicious. Hearty. Great atmosphere.  Though it seemed like a local hang-out (wifi), it was much more friendly towards strangers than most places of this nature.
author: James L.

description: Awesome club sandwich loaded with an incredible amount of toppings. Sandwiches are around 8.50-9.50 and come with a side salad that is very nice. Overall a great pick with friendly and speedy service with a coffee-house feel.
author: Mike F.

description:
I really want to like Velo Rouge--it's on the same block as my boyfriend's apartment. However, when I finally got around to going there this morning, I was really disappointed. I wanted a chai, something warm and caffeinated. What I got (for $3.50, I might add) was a small cup that contained something like warm, banana-flavored milk. I don't know if the barista forgot a step or if their chai is truly unlike anything I've ever had (and I've had a lot of chai), but I don't think I'll be ordering it again unless one or more of you can convince me otherwise.

That all aside, my muffin was really tasty and the cafe is really cute. I'll go back sometime, but perhaps I'll order a hot chocolate instead.
author: Katie I.

description:
Though nail-bitingly slow, this place makes a mean cappuccino.  The crema was thick and frothy and the color of toasted coconuts.  The intensity of the coffee was not overpowered by the roast (i.e. it didn't taste burnt like some places).  All in all, the texture was pure velvet going down my throat.

As we sat in the window keeping an eye on our bikes (2 regular, 1 kick-ass tandem!), the BF and his mom ate some morning bread that contained every healthy ingredient under the sun.  I wasn't in the mood for it, but it certainly looked chock-full of texture, fiber, and roughage.  Heeh.  I used the word "roughage" in a sentence.  

I once got a lemon bar here a long time ago.  Unfortunately I was not in the mood for the food items offered so I didn't eat.  But then again, some people think I'm bat-shit crazy for not liking breakfast foods.  I just don't like scrambled eggs, ok?  You don't like uni.  Don't judge.
author: Christina C.

description:
They have mimosas, they have my heart. 
Mmmm ..mmm.. mmm. mmm. 
Do you know what true love is? I'm not sure either but I sure love how my bacon, eggs, and potatoes complimented my mimosa. So much so, that I had two. 
The atmosphere and folks are as pleasant and charming as the woman who dutifully picked up after her dog outside. What a great start to a Sunday.
author: Loli L.

description: Really good coffee, really good food. Awesome neighborhood cafe with a great sense of community. It's busy for a reason!
author: Robynne W.

description: Great little cafe next to the (Golden Gate) Park in the Inner Richmond. My wife and I sometimes have coffee or breakfast here when we visit my mom who lives just around the corner. I love the Blue Bottle coffee and my wife orders the iced non-fat chai. They also make a pretty good "Mt. Ventoux" egg sandwich served on a croissant with jack cheese, bacon and/or avocado and blueberry coffee cake. Nice place to relax on a nice morning and enjoy a cup of coffee.
author: Serghio P.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop. The food is quite decent (they actually grill the eggs)- and the owner is a talented musician. Good people - good vibe.
author: A S.

description: This place has everything I love: breakfast all day, beer and bicycles.  Easy to get here from work through the Presidio and after spending some time here I can easily get to GG park for more riding.
author: Kristine K.

description:
Now that we're a biking family, we take out our sweet rides and pedal through the Panhandle, then through Golden Gate Park, until we make a pit stop at the Red Bicycle. 

I've found everything to be fresh, from the Jack Johnson pancakes to a bagel with cream cheese and lox; serving Blue Bottle Coffee just makes it all the better. 

It's a little cramped when the weather is nice, and sometimes the line just takes forever, but that doesn't take away from its overall perfectness. Special bonus for having Connect Four!

P.S. I've also heard good things about their Thursday "Melissa Claire's Kitchen" Dinner: http://www.velorougecafe.com/drink.html#melissamenu
author: Nish N.

description: Great brunch spot near USF. I foresee myself spending lots of time here as school is just starting up. I looked around at what people were eating because I'm super indecisive and I like to just pick what looks good. Was intrigued by this girls dish that looked like some sort of veggie scramble. Found out it was the McCallister scramble. It's considered an open faced sandwich because it's all on top of English muffins. There was all kinds of good stuff in there... Spinach mushrooms some cheese I can't remember. And the potatoes were really delicious. This seems like a popular spot so come early if you're hungry it's not the fastest service.
author: Katie P.

description: My friend and I were both on the verge of cranky-town after a cramped commute from the Tenderloin to Golden Gate Park on the 5 during rush hour.  One enormous side salad and soughdough-y pizza later, it was onto a delightful evening.  Very reasonable prices and generous portions.
author: Lynn M.

description:
The best cappuccino I've ever had in this fair city. Don't know how they do it, but it's like a creamy cloud of coffee goodness that I never want to end...

Plus, bike parking is a total win. The food is homemade and pretty tasty and the service is fine. 

BUT THE CAPPUCCINOS...
author: Alexis W.

description:
If you want a laid back place to just chill and eat good sandwiches and a salad, go here! 

I got the leek lentil soup and it was really delicious, very savory and very good for a cold chilly day. I also got the half salad and it had the best combinations----feta, mixed greens, apples, grapes, lemon juice, and so on. Great combo of soup and salad, I was very pleased.

I also came here for breakfast, it's the typical breakfast menu, but if you're hungover---great place! Good life saver.
author: Carissa E.

description:
I'm struggling giving Velo only 4 stars. The coffee (blue bottle) is awesome. The baristas take their time crafting your cup of espresso - not mass produced like other places I won't mention. They serve beer(!!!) offer free wireless, have a bike rack out front and cozy couches. What's there not to love?

1. Parking. It sucks. Which is normal for this neighborhood, but a pain when your driving through and want an awesome cup of coffee.
2. It's the second best cup of coffee I've ever had.
3. The reading material is older than dirt. Small to complain about, but sometimes I just don't want to be on my computer.
4. I can't have it everyday. But that's my fault, not Velo's.
5. They close really early (IMO). Any coffee shop that closes before dark annoys me to no end. Sometimes I want coffee after 6pm.

Otherwise, I love the place and any excuse I can create to stop by. If you've never had coffee @ Velo Rouge, you're doing yourself a disfavor.
author: Sunny D.

description: Not cool for the over-priced mini cups they serve their coffee in. A refill, and you're at one cup total anywhere else... $3.50 for a coffee makes it pretty fancy for a place claiming they're "for the cause&bike friendly." These prices are high and portions are pretty weak... Sorry, not cool.
author: Andy S.

description:
Lately I've been on a kick of trying to rediscover the amazing city that I live in by attempting to patronize the places that I've never been to before but have been on my radar, so when I was craving a cup of coffee to kick start my Sunday, I almost innately knew that I would be stopping by the oh-so-cute Velo Rouge Café to satisfy my caffeine craving. 

I walked in at about 11:30AM and the place was most definitely a'bumpin'! I was pleased to see that they serve Blue Bottle Coffee here -- something that I feel like I should've already known coming in, but perhaps I had just forgotten? Anywho, the bakery treats in the display case are self-serve, which is nice and convenient, but I have to say that I was very dissatisfied with the quality of my selection. I picked out a blackberry scone, which looked fresh and absolutely amazing, but to my chagrin, it had the texture of cardboard, so that was a let down. My coffee, on the other hand, was full-bodied and supremely flavorful, so I left feeling pleased. 

I'm planning on swinging by again when the place is less crowded, for I'd love to be able to actually sit down and savor a nice breakfast here.  The menu is jam-packed with choices and based on the size of the crowd that routinely assembles here on the weekends, they must keep coming back for something good.
author: Katie C.

description:
I use to live about a few blocks away from Velo Rouge, and thought it was just so cute, that I've even made a few trips here when I came up from Milpitas.  It's usually pretty crowded here, especially on the weekends, but if I decide to sit down and eat, I trust the system and always end up getting a table by the time my meal comes.  It is a relatively small coffee shop, I don't think you can really get too much studying done here on the weekend (unless you sit along the side on the stools facing the window) because there are so many people here. It is also very kid friendly, so there's usually a stroller or car seat around you.  There's a few board games, books, and toys for kids to enjoy too.  I don't think you can bring your dog into the cafe but they do have a doggy bowl for water outside.  There's a couple tables outside if you wanna keep your doggy company.

As for the food, I love their sandwich plates and egg plates. (I'd stay away from the breakfast burrito...let's leave that to the Mission.)  Sandwiches come with a side of salad usually including strawberries and blue cheese! The sandys are fancier than your average deli sandy.  Their coffee is really good and if you bring you own mug, you get a small discount.

You should definitely stop on by after or before a stroll in the Park.
author: Mandeep D.

description:
Velo Rouge is a quaint little neighborhood coffee shop tucked behind Golden Gate Park. There is a great selection of coffee and tea, as well as delectable breakfast and lunch options. 

I had the roobois tea (red tea from South Africa) while studying here. The tea was only $2 plus free refill on water. What a perfect way to spend a rainy afternoon. Service was great, restroom was clean, and there was plenty of street parking. Just be sure to move your car every two hours if you're parked in the residential areas. Seating can be a bit difficult if you come during peak lunch hours, but patrons are nice enough to share their space with you. 

Great place! Will be back!
author: Teresa Y.

description: I love coming here on sunny mornings! It's a corner cafe so it's naturally lit well and has outdoor seating. Blue bottle coffee, lots of delicious vegetarian menu options (really good breakfast burrito if you're into those), and endearing bicycle-themed ambiance, very San Francisco if you ask me...
author: Lana L.

description: This place used to be my favorite neighborhood cafe until I moved, & I miss it! It was everything you'd want: great coffee (they sell Blue Bottle coffee), good food, great mimosas & a small selection of beer, awesome atmosphere, indoor & outdoor seating, super friendly staff, locally owned. They even have live music some nights. The only thing I didn't like was that sometimes it'd get crowded & hard to find a seat but that's only because it's such a great place & so well liked.
author: Efrat S.

description:
My honey and I decided to make the trek down here to try it.  I'd definitely have to say that the staff here is a total bummer.  They're really kinda too cool for school.  What is even more strange is that the customers that were in the shop also had that stinky attitude.

Other than that the food was good.  I had the Indurian panini (three cheese grilled sammie on sourdough with tomatoes) and a lentil coconut soup.  Pricey but worth every penny.  I guess I'll put up with the weird vibe again just so I can try everything on the menu.
author: Jeanne L.

description: My husband and I have been a fan of Velo Rouge for years. It's one block away from my mother-in-law's place and Golden Gate Park. It's very homey, and the people that work there are all really nice. We love stopping in here for Blue Bottle coffee (for my husband) and chai (for me) and sometimes a delicious blueberry coffee cake.  Really cute neighborhood place where you can spend a lazy weekend relaxing with friends or read a book.
author: Julie P.

description:
Been hearing about the Velo Rouge Cafe serving Blue Bottle Coffee in the Richmond District.  Funny, as I lived close by in the early 90s, I never knew about this place.  That is because it has been here for only a year or so.

I've been here for both breakfast and lunch.  Both times I get the double espresso which is a mainstay from me.  The espresso has a nice foam on top and has a nice flavor going down.  Most excellent.  For breakfast, I get the Mt. Ventoux breakfast sandwich.  It's an egg sandwich w/ jack cheese on croissant.  I add bacon to the sandwich as an extra.  For lunch, we have had the Pantani (grilled veggie/jack cheese) and Merckx (ham & swiss) sandwiches.  Each sandwich is grilled and comes with a side salad.  The salad is pretty robust with feta, sliced apple, corn and blueberry - surprisingly tasty.  Everything here is very good.

Added perks in the front of the cafe are the 2 doggie water bowls and the tire pump with Presta/Schrader valve both in one.  The Velo Rouge cafe is a welcome and much needed addition to the Richmond District.  You guys rock!!
author: Janet H.

description:
I was expecting, I don't know, coffee and some good-enough sandwiches from this place. It would probably have no problem staying in business doing just that, given its proximity to the park.

When I came in, all sweaty and nasty smelling, I was over the moon to find that they not only have delicious organic food, but that they serve blue bottle coffee. I am never having lunch anywhere else in the neighborhood again.

Also, I don't have to feel shy about being in spandex and smelling like dog. Everyone else does too. Fabulous!
author: H G.

description:
When I'm in town, I visit this place. I don't go out of my way, mind you-it just happens to be near my friends' place. 

Usually, when I come in here, it's in the late morning/early afternoon and most often fighting a massive hangover. This place is very good for that. Specifically, I order a Mt. Vonteux and maybe some tea. If I can score a table, this helps immeasurably. 

The only downside is just that-seating. It's usually packed to the gills, and you have to be prepared to take your food and retreat somewhere else to actually eat it. Maybe everyone has similar nights. Or they just like the laid back environment.
author: Steve A.

description: Good dishes (including breakfast all day), good coffee (Blue Bottle), and a friendly atmosphere. Main drawback is that it gets crowded and hard to find seating on weekends.
author: William C.

description:
Yum :) Love that place! I always have their Moroccan lentil peasant pie with a side salad- it's oh so good. Plus members of the bike coalition get a discount.
Get there early during lunch time though, because the place is tiny and fills out really quickly.
author: Marie M.

description:
I literally have spent more time at Velo Rouge than my own house. Yes, it's hard to get seating during certain times. However, I walk in and the entire staff says hi to me. They serve Blue Bottle Coffee which is my favorite, and they know how to make it well.

Breakfast: The breakfast burrito. Massive (I always share it), it is stuffed with eggs, cheese, black beans, avocado, sour cream, potatoes, and it comes with chips and salsa.

Lunch: The soups and salad are always good, but sandwich-wise I would stick to the Coppi (turkey, cheese, spinach, jam) or the Pantani (grilled veggies and cheese done panini style). There is also live music here on certain nights, and free wifi.
author: D S.

description: No wifi on weekends!! Went here to have a nice cup of joe and catch up on work. I was the only person in the cafe with a computer! I asked the waiter twice if he could make a consideration to turn on wifi, and he was rude about it. Not coming back.
author: Anitha R.

description:
Tasty, albeit a bit pricey, coffee and treats.

Blue Bottle!

Bikes!

Brilliant!
author: Lesley P.

description: I love the Velo Rouge.  My understanding is they switched owners a few years ago and it seems like something improved beyond the decor.  My wife and I often go over on Sunday mornings to do laundry at the place next door, and it's full of SF's young and beautiful, making it a lively and warm place.  The staff is consistent, many I've seen there for years, and they never seem to hold that typical retail resentment-under-the-smile.  The intermittent wifi is a pain, sometimes, but I get the point because they have a small space to cram all the people in and want it to become the library when busy. Fair enough.  On the upside, there's the random encounters we've often had by virtue of having to share table space with others.  The decor is warm and funky and fun.  A+.
author: Lynn C.

description: Excellent coffee and even better eats.  The breakfast coffee cake is to die for!  Everything on the lunch menu is awesome and free WiFi.  Seating is a bit limited during peak hours as well as parking but overall a great place for coffee and a bite to eat.
author: Matt J.

description:
Damn good coffee. Like crack. 

Delicious high quality sandwiches with confused but scrumptious savory/sweet salads.  

Free wifi. Lots of natural light. Lots of bike parking. Pictures of bikes on the wall. 

I'll see you at the red bicycle.
author: Anthony S.

description:
This place is always busy as hell. I don't know if that is a good or bad thing. After Mac bought the place from Meg, I feel that the food went up a notch.

I used to live next door to this place before I moved to the Panhandle. I haven't check out Melissa's Claire's Kitchen or their Pizza nights yet, but it is definitely on the to-do list. I believe that they have various events during the week too. I am a huge fan of their breakfast sandwiches.
author: Joel L.

description:
Very cool vibe the minute you walk in the door. The staff is very personable and don't mind if you chill for a while reading the paper or doing your homework. 

I enjoy that the coffee does not come out of a large stainless steel container like some places around town and is brewed-to-order.
author: David A.

description: 3 and a half stars would be more accurate. Bad service, good food, and the blue bottle coffee is excellent. The vibe inside is very cute and you can imagine your in a little cafe in Paris.
author: Robert C.

description: They serve breakfast burritos? Count me in.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
I LOVEEEEEEEEEEEEEE mom n pop cafes! I also love that it is within walking distance for me. Yeah, this place is on the smaller side, but how awesome is it that a cafe is dedicated to cyclers/cycling? Ok, fine, I won't act as if I myself is a cycler, but my bf was and pointed this out. From the name of the cafe to the names on the menu and of course, they have a pump for your bicycle if it's low on air outside. 

I do have to confess though, that I've only had the iced mocha here. But it's yummy! And once I find something yummy, I don't want to try anything else. One day I'll try a different drink and have a yummy sandwich. 

Anyway, great place to hang out and study. And plus, you'll be supporting a mom n pop. Oh yeah, did I mention I LOVEEEEEEEEEEEEEE mom n pops?
author: Eugenia G.

description: Okay, writing this review while scarfing down a pizza and the soup of the day. My wife and we went here because we got a gift certificate as an engagement gift...THANK YOU KAREN! This little place is amazing!!! I am for sure going to be back for a "long day of work after work reward." the service was perfect -- wait staff was super friendly, she let us try the wine first, which was really good ($4 glass o Zin, yum)! And the pizza; it was so amazing; an explosion of deliciousness and perfect harmony of flavor. Do yourself a huge flavor and check this place out! Service, wine, food, all perfect -- went on a Wednesday a 7; 3 other people here, really chill atmosphere...for me it's hard to get better than this!
author: Dustin T.

description:
Along came mid-terms & a paper about Ethics in Journalism. Per usual, I procrastinated until the last possible moment to whoop that bad boy out. I won't bore you with the details about the paper...but I managed to spend 5 hours doing it at Velo Rouge cafe.

My day started with the The Indurain; Jack, Swiss, Cheddar & Sliced Tomatoes on a Sourdough Roll--pretty damn good. I finished lunch, and started typing away. 

After about 5 pages, it was time for a mid-afternoon cookie break. I'm a cookie monster if you haven't figured that out from the trend of my recent reviews. Velo Rouge comes through--soft & fresh cookies & a tall glass of milk for $2.75. 

The cookie was finished, milk mustache in full-effect & I was on the home stretch for my 10-page paper. I burned out a few more pages, wrapped it up & then decided it was time for a celebratory beer.

CHIMAY!!! 
Mmmmm....sweet sweet beer.
I love you.

Matter of fact, I had two.

While not the cheapest spot, Velo Rouge Cafe offers a great selection of food, coffee/tea & even good beer. 

And they have FREE INTERNETS!!!
author: matt m.

description: I like the bagel sandwiches, but the scrambles and french toast (topped with berries and bananas) are awesome too. Blue botttle coffee location...  If I could justify 5 stars for a breakfast place, this would be it!  They have friendly baristas and waitstaff folks there.  And it's super bike and dog friendly.  We typically call in our sandwiches if eating lunch and they're always ready!
author: Chris M.

description:
I am very oblivious at times. Well, most of the time. I have probably passed this place about a million times and never even knew it existed. And then I came for a friend's birthday.

How did I not know this was here? This place is fantastic. I didn't eat, but the food looked great. They have a nice selection of wine and beer - and non-alcoholic beverages, but why would you want that since I just told you they have beer and wine? Are you pregnant? On meds? Just coming out of rehab? Belonging to a religion which prohibits alcohol? Fine, suit yourself. More wine for me.

The people who work here are absolutely wonderful - and they had a nice and friendly mix of people. I can't remember the last time I had conversations with so many strangers in this city. Why don't people have random conversations with strangers in this city? Why is it necessary to pretend the people around you don't exist? I don't know, but that's not how it was here.

They have a nice little outside area - perfect for sneaking a smoke (with your drink - it's allowed). I can't wait for the next sunny day to head back down here for an afternoon glass of wine and a small bite to eat.
author: Suge K.

description:
Further update -- the Velo Rouge now makes pizzas on Wednesday and Friday nights. No mere warmed over cheese bar pizzas these, oh no. Robust, complex and slathered with fresh veggies and juicy hunks of heirloom tomatoes, these scrumptious, unctuous 10" wonders make the VRC a destination pizza spot along the lines of Pizzetta 211. 

Mac, the chef/owner, is modest about his talents as a pizzaiolo, but really,  they're wicked good.
author: Douglas G.

description: My favorite coffee shop in Inner Richmond!!! They serve Blue Bottle Coffee, which is a good enough excuse to go there, but everything about this place is amazing. Their breakfast and brunch specials are delicious, with fresh and high-quality ingredients.  Not to mention, the atmosphere is intimate and hip. A great place to study, have brunch with friends, or just hang out!
author: Bridget B.

description: This place is busy and seems like they have a good amount of local folks.  Stopped in on my way to work to grab a breakfast burrito with only 1 person in front of me in line.  The girl ahead of me ordered a coffee and a hot breakfast.  Within a couple of mins, a line had formed and wouldn't you know that everyone else behind me received their order first.  The girl who was in front of me had to ask for her order and 25 mins later, I get my breakfast burrito.  It was bland and certainly not worth the $8.65.  There was no meat, barely any eggs and maybe just a slice of avocado.  Basically got  black beans and a burnt tortilla. The girl at the register was a bit clueless and the other 2 guys were not all that friendly either.  NEVER AGAIN!
author: Chris P.

description:
I was reminded of this place because they underwrite my favorite radio station (KUSF 90.3FM people!), and lately I can not pass by without stopping for an AWESOME cup of coffee!  It's Blue Bottle Coffee, which is handy because that way I am supporting two of my fave small businesses at once.  They make this little latte called a Lone Mountain, which is like a cappuccino with a tiiiny bit more milk, and less foam.  It's just right.

They also have a great selection of sandwiches and breakfast-type foods, plus other unusual and desirable beverages, like wine and beer.

The african dinner guy is gone, but I was reading the new gal's weekly dinner menu and it looks GOOD.  I haven't tried it yet, but it looked quite enticing, with a local and seasonal focus.

Besides the coffee, my favorite thing is the sign on the back of a high-chair, which said, "Unattended children will be given espresso and a free puppy." Haha!  Love it.
author: Teal H.

description:
You can only guess that since i am a biker that i loved this cafe. The decked out bike hanging in front of the door and all the pictures on the wall inside were great touches!

They serve blue bottle coffee, so it's amazing.
Didn't get a chance to try the food but it smelt damn good.

Will absolutely be returning to this cafe in the near future!!
author: Susanna B.

description:
You know what happens when you run from class to mid-term thesis defense to interview to interview?

You forget to eat lunch.  You forget to even pee.  You are so rushed that you are incredulous when you discover (standing at Fulton and Arguello) you have twenty minutes until you have to be at interview number two... what to do?  What to do?
