Here is where Velo Rouge Cafe comes in handy because of the following:

1. They have coffee (to stave off hunger pains until one gets home to consume late lunch of ramen noodles.)
2. They have a bathroom in which to evacuate the previous four cups of coffee you've used to stave off the hunger pains until this point.

What can I say about Velo Rouge Cafe?  It's $2 for a small coffee... that's kinda pricey; but, they hand brew each cup... so it's almost worth it.

Plus the guys who work there are really nice.

They had coffee and a bathroom; and, appeared to have free WiFi... not to mention a charming atmosphere.

Soooooo... four stars...  I'll be back.
author: Kate R.

description:
Here's the deal -- Now that I live out here in what another ex-Manhattanite dismissively called the "Queens of SF", I'm all up for pimpin' the Richmond District (We need a cool realtor's made-up nickname out here - The RiDi? Richmo'? Fogmondo? Throw me a freakin' bone here, people...) - and the Velo Rouge is one of the things that makes the livin' easy.

They pull good espresso (not sure about the Illy versus a more local bean for juicin', but Dr. Illy's dark-roasted cluster bombs from Trieste are still nothing to sneeze at) and they know their way around making that into a latte or a macchiato. And I can only say I've tried a few baked goods and the Mt. Ventoux sandwich, but I proclaim all to be excellent. Add to that the outside tables (Arguello is kinda the fogline by afternoon here, so you can actually get some sun there) and the dogfriendliness, and this is an excellent place. 

I do wonder why they don't have an Armstrong entree on the bike-centric menu (Merckx, Coppi, even an Indurain -- but no Armstrong)

And I am looking forward to trying the Radio Africa Thursday night dinner --- looks very cool indeed.
author: T C.

description: I've been coming to this place for about 6 years so far. I've seen this place go from one ownership to another and the food and service has been fantastic throughout all those years. The food and drinks are by far really amazing, fresh and organic. It's kid and family friendly. Park your bike right outside, and come on in or take it to go. They make drinks really quickly and there is a large indoor and outdoor seating arrangement.
author: Cody A.

description: A perfect "Around the Corner" coffee shop. Blue Bottle Coffee, and the breakfast burritos are great! They're happy hour is a pretty sweet deal also -- $4 wine & $3 beer. Not too shabby.   Sometimes they burn the coffee tho. And it can get crowded. But thats only cause its a great hang out spot! Two thumbs up Velo Rouge.
author: Lauren R.

description:
It's your typical cafe. If you leave nearby, you will come. Nothing will surprise you about this place except that it isn't Starbucks. 

The line and wait is always long in the popular morning hours, so that kind of prevented me from grabbing something to go before work. If you want to hang out and manage to get a seat, observe people. I learned all the different faces pretentious San Franciscans make by doing this!

The food and drinks are good but a little pricey. They also seem to serve dinner and have events which look very intimate. I can't vouch for that though.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Going to Velo Rouge is like having a relationship with someone that can be thoughtless/irritating but that you know is a quality person, so you give them the benefit of the doubt and are friends with them in spite of it.

The place is right around the corner from my house and serves blue bottle coffee, a good menu of breakfast and lunch things, and great beers. It also has outdoor seating and the decor/vibe of the place is great, always a nice mix of families, cyclists, and indietastic twentysomethings in there. Also, connect four is provided. 

Several issues prevent me from raving about this place, but to be clear, I have been there probably 50 times and will always go there. 

First, don't ever go there unless you have infinite time. Seriously. The staff (varies from great, nice people, and apathetic/sloth hipsters) is completely unconcerned with time and often chats with customers for several minutes before moving through the line of people.  If you are stopping on the way to work for coffee or trying to catch the bus, you'll want to kill someone. They no longer do the drip filters for the coffee but you can NEVER be in and out in less than 8 minutes, even if you are just getting coffee. If you're getting food, even just a bagel, plan on 20-25 minutes. 

Second, they only accept card for purchases over $10 and when I bought blue bottle beans to comply with this minimum they refused to grind the beans for me even though they have a grinder, I guess its some blue bottle policy.  Also, though the food is pretty tasty, the portions are never quite enough to really fill you which is a bit bothersome given that is not cheap.  

Finally, they close at 3:00 pm on Mondays and Tuesdays. Frustrating.
author: Sara A.

description:
I used to live right next to VRC, so I went there often out of convenience. It's a cute enough cafe, I totally appreciate having it in the neighborhood as there's not much else around and it's great that it's an independent business. They also have a bike pump locked up to the bike rack outside, which I think is a really great thing. The food and coffee (Blue Bottle) are both pretty good too, but definitely overpriced. 

There's only really one nice person that works here and everyone else is kind of a jerk. Most of the customers are also kind of jerks - it's definitely a weird vibe. There's usually only one person taking orders and making coffee so the drinks take a little while. But there's always at least three people working in the kitchen so it's a little irritating that it takes forevvvver to get a bagel, especially when the people that work there are just standing around gossiping instead of working.
author: Emily F.

description: This breakfast burrito is to die or at least ride 53 miles (inside joke for those who have been there) for. Eggs, black beans, cheese and many other tasty ingredients.  Blue Bottle Coffee, great ambiance and artwork.  Highly recommend for any bicycle lovers
author: Mike T.

description:
I wish I could say I liked this place better. It has all the potential to be my awesome neighborhood coffee shop--being that I could walk on my hands from my home to here (this skill comes in handy from my pre-teen gymnast days.) Unfortunately, it never seems to be open when I walk by (granted, it's a coffee shop, but they do serve beer) and the vibe inside is a little too-cool-for-the-Inner-Rich. Don't really know who to blame, but I'm guessing it has to do with that too-cute bike pump out in front. I think it pumps out pretentiousness. 

A disgruntled ex-patron I know very well has resorted to calling the workers here "Bourgeois monkey-faces" because typically, they've been pretty snotty. We appreciate the hipness of the space and cyclist décor, but it'd be nice to enjoy without the attitude once in awhile. 

I'd love to try the Radio Africa nomad dinner that takes place here, if I can get over my sour predisposition of the location and the staff. And I will. I just know it. 

I will press on to give this place more chances. Why? Because, it's freakin' cute. It's different. It's got a bicycle theme (even with the evil pump.) And I'd like to see more of these unique bars and restaurants and shops appear on this street. And I'd take this place with all of its attitude and bizarre hours any day over an "It's a Grind" ticky-tacky establishment that makes everything just look all the same.
author: Kelly R.

description: Good coffee and pastries. Love coming here for breakfast. They also make a mean soy chai latte...
author: James P.

description:
Velo is a quaint cafe near Golden Gate park with a cycling theme to it. There are four sandwiches available:

The Coppi - named for Italian cyclist Fausto Coppi, aka Il Campionissimo "The greatest champion" - a turkey, spinach, & jack sandwich.

The Merckx - the Belgian "cannibal" who many consider to be the best cyclist ever - the sandwich is a ham and swiss (?).  There is a great debate as to whether Merckx or Coppi was the best cyclist ever.  I am sure simply trying each sandwich out is ONE way to settle it.

The Pantani - Il Pirata before Johnny Depp claimed the role.  One of Italy's most beloved cyclists - the sandwich is a grilled veggie and jack.

The Indurain - Spain's finest rider, "Miguelon"  - the sandwich is a three cheese and sundried tomato.

I can't comment on all the sandwiches -- just the Merckx, which was fine even if it did take me 2 hours to work the mustard seeds out of my teeth. 

The location of the cafe near the park is solid, and the food is fine.  I wish everything about the place was bigger -- a roomier interior, a larger menu, etc. etc.  But, I will be back soon to examine the Coppi-Merckx debate...
author: Tim G.

description:
I'm a big fan of "F" words when it comes to restaurants... FOOD and FREE!! The food is delicious, and the free wireless is a huge brownie point!

The food is organic and they have my fav Blue Bottle Coffee.  I could have died and gone to heaven after eating The Merckx sandwich, which features ham and cheese toasted on sourdough.  They also serve all sandwiches with side salads.  This "F"rickin' "F"abolous "F"aire is recommended :)
author: Jenni D.

description:
This place grew on me.

I had been in a sublet nearby for a couple months, cursed to a life without internet at home. I had no choice but to come to Velo Rouge, as it offered the most accessible internet nearby. In that context of desperation, the fact that it closed early Saturday-Tuesday did not endear me to it.

But, phew, let's just enjoy it as a neighborhood cafe: I don't need regular internet to survive. Let's just go and read a book. Let's just relax. Let's get an Americano for the bus, because I do need regular coffee to survive. The quality of your coffee is hugely dependent on your barista, but try not to worry too much about it.

Are you an SF bike club member? Be sure to flash your card for 10% off--icing on the cake!
author: Brian S.

description:
I hate finding lunch around work. It's always a huge struggle. But I spent brunch here one lovely morning with some colleagues and visiting colleagues from out of town, and I was pleasantly surprised with the atmosphere (bus-ay, baby). I didn't expect too much out of the food, but boy was I wrong. I had the McAlister that was eggs, spinach, feta, bacon and english muffin action. No bacon for me, darling. Bomb. Tiny ass plate though, but it's a great starter for my day.

I am pleased however, to say that the coffee was the treat. Jacob makes one mean latte, and I mean MEAN. Flossy, bomb, sharp, foamy cup of love. thanks, it really made my day. I've been living with inferior lattes as of late, but you have redeemed the latte back to its most favored status. 

What, you think I'm lying? Get thee to the Velo. Get Jacob to froth you up some latte. And see who's lying now! 

PS: I'm a sucker for anything Tour de France related and I SO know who the names of the Paninis refer to. Stuff like that makes me gushy inside. What a dork.
author: Charlene L.

description:
When are you open??
Not at 6:15, when I leave for work.  
Not at 5:30 when I return from work.

Love the espresso, but can't handle the hours.  
I'd love to grab an espresso on my way downtown, but can't; would LOVE to grab a glass of wine on my way back, but can't.
author: laura g.

description:
The place is nice and cute, and I would spend a lot of time there if it was in my neighborhood.

They serve Blue Bottle coffee which is the best on earth IMHO, and I've had serveral food items and they are good as well.

The service is to be watched.  They seem to not pay attention to what they ask and though I wouldn't consider them to be full-on hipsters, there is still the scent of hipster aroma and to me, it's just not needed.

It's very tiny and can get very crowded during the weekend AM.  Free internet!
author: Josh L.

description: While I live within a few houses of Velo Rouge I rarely visit. I cannot blame this on Velo Rouge itself but more so the obnoxious people that frequent. I finally decided to stop in and get a small breakfast last weekend while waiting on a friend. While my food was fine (egg sandwich, no meat) the atmosphere is chaotic and passive aggressive. I'm talking kids running around without parental concern, people cutting in line, cramped spaces near the register and coffee station, cut-throat stealing of drink orders; not to mention having to overhear conversations filled with umms, likes, dudes and other idiotic bimbo speech regarding boys and partying. I do like their coffee and the fine selection of doggies that sometimes frequent the outdoor tables.
author: Cori W.

description:
There are three things that I found particularly enjoyable here that catapulted Velo Rouge above 3 stars:

1) family style seating... too few establishments go that extra step of being a neighborhood place. Really adds to the vibe. Also, they didn't overcrowd the place. Too many restaurants do that and it's annoying.
2) service is exceptional. I mean, really exceptional
3) price point is fair. 

We didn't have a reservation so had to give up our table - fair. They let us dine at the bar. Prix Fixe menu - we couldn't order the halibut because of the reservations for the night - also very fair. They had apparently anticipated or asked during reservation to plan accordingly. I really liked that. The spinach and ricotta ravioli was divine, btw. Could have gone for a different dessert, it was just average.

All in all, I do look forward to coming back on a non-thursday. Every thursday is fixed menu full four-course dinner. Every other night you can take advantage of their big tables and wi-fi and cheap excellent coffee.

Will look forward to getting to know this little place better.
author: Annie T.

description:
I enjoy coming to this coffee shop when its a sunny day.
I think their open close times are a little odd though.

I love the fact that they have sugar syrup for me. Because sugar syrup just blends in better when i have a cold drink versus sugar, cause sugar crystals just don't dissolve in cold drinks.

The food here is good too. I never got around to doing their restaurant eating, and neither did I sit in to their live shows.

So I mainly liked to go here when it was a sunny day. It has a warm and friendly feel and I love how dogs are everywhere.
However, most of the times during the sunny days it was hard to find seats.

But its a good place for bikers too. (Hence being called velo-rouge, velo meaning bike) It's a block away from golden gate park. And has a place for you to lock your bikes and I even recall seeing a bike pump.

Personally I give it three stars, but considering I didn't do most of the other things they offered, I gave it a 4 cause I know other people have enjoyed the other things they've had to offer.
author: Michelle L.

description:
2 stars.  Slow, painfully slow slow SLOW scene at this place...and that was before they started doing the drip coffee to order.

The wannabe punk rock guy behind the counter is SLOW and not too intelligent...there is always a confused South American guy wandering around with plates of overpriced food...and the place is always stuffy and uncomfortable.

They get points for style and for appealing for being 'nice' and all, but aside from that, either plan to get there 10 minutes early if you want coffee, or go somewhere else!
author: Matt O.

description:
This is a cute  little neighborhood cafe, but every time I've ordered anything it takes them ages to bring it out.  How long does it take to toast a bagel and put a pad of butter on it?

***UPDATE***

I was entirely too hard on this spot.  I've decided it's a cute little cafe outfitted with a decent menu and nice atmosphere.  On Thursdays, they have Radio Africa, a $25 price-fix menu which is supposed to be quite good.
author: Krista C.

description:
I finally stopped in this afternoon, after driving past this place a million times and telling myself  "I should check it out!" ..... Love it, too!!!! 
Totally adorable spot, with friendly staff. The owner, Meg, is super friendly and I really hope the business does well- she was saying that it's pretty quiet in the afternoons- maybe the USF students just don't know about the place yet???? 

Their soup today was gingery butternut squash, which really hit the spot... yum! For $5 a generous portion served with sourdough toast slices...

The space is BRIGHT with large windows so you can see all the adorable dogs walking by.... Parking is okay (a plus if you have an L permit)... Adorable big red bike rack, outside, too. 

The place is impeccably CLEAN. Which, as my fellow yelpers will understand, is HUGE in my book. 

Here are their hours: 
Monday - Wednesday
6:30am - 3pm
Thursday & Friday
6:30am - 10pm
Saturday & Sunday
8am -5pm

Radio Africa & Kitchen
Every Thursday, 6:30-9:30pm
Live Music Every Friday Night 

http://www.velorougecafe.com/
check it out sometime!!!
author: M'ia K.

description:
Very cool little cafe with AWESOME coffee plus they have CONNECT FOUR, only the greatest game EVER!! After losing the first couple games and having a hearty well priced (only $6.00!) meal of 2 eggs over easy, country potatoes and toast with some really good cranberry jam, I came back to win two in a row and boisterously declared myself CONNECT FOUR CHAMPION OF THE WORLD!!

So if anyone wishes to challenge my title, you know where to find me... at the Velo Rouge Cafe!
author: Ali C.

description:
Hurray for bicycles! I had the same teacher for 5th and 6th grade, because I went to a very small school (that's why I'm odd), anyway I hated her, because she had her desk planted right in front of the window and would always bust me trying to stare past her big fat head at my bike. But I LOVED my bike and all I wanted it to do was ride around on it all day. So I grew up and eventually got a new bike (I outgrew my banana seat years ago) and I still feel the same way about my bike. 

If you share in this sort of bicycle enthusiasm you may want to stop by Velo Rouge on a ride sometime.  They have a super cool bike rack and are cyclist friendly through and through - not to mention very nice people with cool T-shirts for sale. A great place to sip a coffee and grab a snack. From the looks of the sandwiches I am guessing this is a good place for lunch as well.
author: J F.

description:
One of the best espresso houses in SF -- just a slight notch below Ritual and Blue Bottle (although they use Blue Bottle beans).  Great vibe, super friendly staff (owner Mac is great, as was the previous owner Meg).

Only caveats are, if you're a cafe worker like me, that they close early Mon & Tues, Th evenings are for dinners, and Fridays often rearrange chairs for bands -- which are great as long as you know to expect them.  One Th I was there, the dinner was canceled, and they closed early -- sucked.

Fantastic carrot cake!  (I'm normally not a big fan ;-)
author: Ari M.

description:
The place is really cute, I have been in the neighborhood for over half year and heard about many good things about this place and always saw a lot people.  Finally I have decided to visit on a Friday afternoon, and it was just great. 

Some staff didn't seem to be so friendly, but I think once the owner gets there the atmosphere changes and he was just super friendly and welcoming and i even enjoyed watching his interaction with other customers; really feels like a neighborhood cafe!!

on friday evenings they have live music and wednesdays movie nights.  they do have some vegan meals but given i am quite particular about my intake i did not have the chance to try.  As far as coffee, since i do not drink coffee either so it is difficult to judge how good it is.  But i do love the atmosphere, it's just very enjoyable to be there, when there are not so many people.  

Note it can get really crowded...
author: Sharon L.

description:
Service: 4/5
Food: 4/5
Wait: 4/5
Price: $$
Portions: 3/5
Presentation of food: 5/5
Presentation of restaurant: 5/5
Overall: 5/5


Their dripping coffee is the best of the best. i never had any better coffee! this little cafe, is on the corner; very homie feeing to it. friendly workers (: i came originally for their panini sandwiches, and i ended having a cup of their dripping coffee before i headed out the door. and oh my lord was it delightful. its superrr smooth, nice and rich, strong enough to keep me energized for the rest of the day. one cup is all you need. and for me personally im a caffeine addict, i can have up to 3 cups of coffee; but this place set it off by just 1 amazing cup. i suggest drinking it there and enjoy it  :) the only thing is that it takes couple minutes because of its dripping, but the time pays off once u get a whip of that coffee! yummmm-o! speaking of it, i just had a cup earlier today! ^.^ haha.
author: Eva H.

description: After a very taxing attempt to grab a cab from Polk and Bush, we finally got a cab and winded up here. Sure, the anecdotal story is unnecessary but it trully explains how much my BF and I needed a cup of coffee. This was serious business since it was a journey to get to the Reddit meetup. We got our drinks to go, he had a drip and I had a chai latte. I feel that lately I've been overusing the word "delicious" in my reviews so instead I'll say it was a perfect blend and while you couldn't quite distinguish the spices, you did have the hint of sweetness (honey, maybe) which meant that it ended on a perfect note.
author: Shauna S.

description: Being a vegetarian, I felt like an idiot after ordering an egg dish and not realizing it had bacon. They kindly remade it for me free of charge. The waiters/waitresses are so sweet. Definitely coming back.. The coffee is excellent too.
author: m H.

description: This place is prime.  I've only been here once and I probably would have never discovered it had it not been for my friend.  Went here around 12 for brunch and they have a great menu.  I had a mocha which was great and fresh.  Their food was fantastic.  This is a supreme spot for a kickback breakfast on a Saturday morning before heading to GG Park
author: Alex G.

description:
Okay, I admit, I'm trying to turn the inner Richmond around...and, the owner of Velo Rouge is on my team! Just what the neighborhood needs...a cafe, right on the bicycle route into the park, that is daring enough to be painted red, and serves breakfast and lunch. Love it! 
Next time you just happen to be in the foggy inner Richmond, Velo should be your place to warm up with a hot cup of Joe. I'm telling you, the inner Richmond is where its at.
author: jodes l.

description:
I go for the sandwiches, blue bottle coffee, and friendly staff.

I stay for the outside seating, free wifi, happy hour, and finger puppets.
author: Taylor E.

description: This place gets busy and loud so it's not great for studying and my coffee had an acidic aftertaste, but all of the food looks really good.  Instead of studying, I kept looking at everyone's plates and thinking "I need to order that next time."
author: M. N.

description:
Velo Rouge has everything you look for in a neighborhood cafe... good coffee, good variety of food, entertainment (as in movie nights and live music) and a casual sense of community. I particularly enjoyed the Mt. Ventoux breakfast sandwich which basically consists of baked eggs with jack cheese on a deliciously buttered croissant. Though a bit undersized in comparision to a Manhattan variant, the cream cheese and lox bagel with capers makes a good noontime nosh.

As it says on their $1 stickers, "VRC" avoids the pretentious pitfalls of so many urbanite cafes by catering to its Inner Richmond cliental with a good dose of friendly and fast service. And a cafe that serves up Bloody Mary's and beer is one that I will go to again. After all, one cannot live solely on coffee alone.

Definite 4-Yelp star status. =)
author: Be N.

description:
This place is an excellent corner Cafe.  Great for breakfast and lunch.   For breakfast I highly recommend the Mt. Ventoux.  They have price fixed dinners Monday through Wednesday - sorta pricey, but excellent healthy dishes.  

Oh, and their coffee is outstanding.  Local bands usually play during the weekends.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I drink black coffee. I ask for black coffee. Most good coffee shops in this  town make drip coffee. The problem is, besides the premium price for drip coffee, most places give you 3/4 of a cup, assuming you want cream. 

I don't want cream, and i believe there are many like-minded people who also do not want to spice up their coffee with cream and sugar, after all its premium good coffee. 

So when a barista asks me if i want my coffee black and I affirm that to be my desire and then I get a full cup of delicious drip blue bottle coffee, that place deserves mention, and some stars
author: Per M.

description:
I came here on a warm and sunny day with my bf for some BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE. We relaxed outside and managed to play some games provided by the cafe. 

This place is perfect if youve had a tiring or bad day. Just grab a cup of coffee, a pastry or dish, choose a seat and you can stay as long as you wish. 

The noise volume here is not too loud and they have great music here. And after your coffee break, why not hit GG park and take a stroll for some more detoxing? Or hit up Rossi Park.  Both are just a block away
author: Van D.

description:
First, the good: the coffee (fantastic), the atmosphere (it's always lively in there), the staff (very friendly), the place itself, the patio, the free wifi and the quirky furniture. The fact that it's a block away from my house helps.

Now, there are two things that are not so good. First, I don't know think that it's a place where you would come to study or do some serious reading, even though I saw a number of people doing it. It's simply too loud most of the times. I realize that this contradicts my previous statement about the liveliness of the place ;)

Second, the breakfast items that I had were quite small. They should definitely increase their portions, given the number of hungry cyclists that sit there everyday :). Also, the scrambled eggs were just that, scrambled eggs, quite bland.
author: Dumitru E.

description:
I've passed the Velo Rouge a hundred times or more & always thought it looked nice, but there are enough quaint, cool, unpretentious indy coffee shops in SF, & the VR is too far.

That is, until my dear friend Rebecca (who recently left her job & has been freelancing from home) told me that she's worked on her laptop from there several times now, & its her new favorite haunt. Color me officially intrigued.

This past weekend, the girlfriend & I had plans to hit up the De Young, but wanted a good spot to grab breakfast & coffee on the way. Bingo!

I was NOT disappointed. I got bacon egg & cheese on an english muffin & a cafe au lait, she got chai & a breakfast burrito, & it was all de-goddamn-licious. We sat outside in the sunshine & marvelled at how nice & quiet this little microneighborhood is. The little spot behind USF, not quite the Panhandle, but not quite the Richmond. I've got friends who moved just a few blocks away recently, & they call it the Richandle.

Being in an area with a handful of decent coffee joints where nothing quite stands out from the pack, I am officially jealous of them for having the Velo Rouge in their backyard. This is an incredibly cool & charming local indy coffee shop, & I will be back.
author: Pete J.

description: The soups and salads are great.  The soups are made fresh & you can really taste it. Friendly staff with good prices.  A great value!
author: Donna W.

description:
Very good coffee, extremely nice people.

They managed to out-nice every other coffee house in the neighborhood while I was living there.

The Blue Bottle coffee is very tasty, and worth the extra $0.50 compared to other local places, methinks.

Oh, man... One more thing... You can get a bagel with Nutella AND cream cheese here. Is it just me, or is that f*ckin' awesome?
author: Angelo B.

description: Followed Yelp to this place while staying in the neighborhood for the week.  The food was excellent and very affordable, the coffee is the best in the neighborhood (Blue Bottle I believe), and the service was friendly and prompt.  We went back for breakfast a second morning!
author: Sarah W.

description:
After attending a wonderful Radio Africa night I decided to stop in for brunch on a Saturday to check out the actual cafe. 

Two friends and I stopped in and took our time making our breakfast choices. The sandwiches and meals all sounded good, but settled on an english muffin sandwich--I  think it was called the McAllister. I thought to myself ok, english muffins are small, how do you make a satisfying sandwich worth $6.50? I just assumed that they included potatoes or maybe used an extra large English muffin or something.

Well, of course I assumed wrong. The waitress brought an egg sandwich on a little english muffin. It was tasty enough, but I want by Saturday brunch to fill me up, and the english muffin didn't do the trick. One of my friends had different kind of sandwich on toast, so it was a bit larger, but we were all disappointed. For the price we expected more. To add insult to injury I ordered a latte, but hadn't received it when the waitress brought the sandwich, so i reminded her...she simply said I forgot, and after another 5  minutes or so brought me my drink. Needless to say I had finished my sandwich about 3 minutes earlier.

Perhaps I make it sound worse than it was, but I'm just disappointed because I had high hopes for this cute little place.
author: Lara L.

description:
Cute, independent cafe with friendly staff.  Minuses are limited hours, prices are moderate, there are often no seats to be had, and though there is free wifi (yay!), the wall sockets are almost completely destroyed.

Great place to walk to in the inner Richmond, though.
author: Lauren J.

description: This place is a GREAT find. Little shop on the corner done right! Great service and good food! I've played music here too and the owner was awesome to work with!
author: Andrew H.

description: Sometimes I walk up to Golden gate park on Arguello and I always pass this place by. Always full, filled with bicyclers, which is cool.  Well yesterday I really wanted a panini and my favorite place didn't sell paninis anymore so I had to find a alternative. So my friend took me here and I got The Merckx which was grilled cheese & ham with dijon mustard. It was pretty tasty, better if it was hot though but I didn't eat it right away so it was my fault. Didn't care much for the salad though but besides that good place.
author: Julie Z.

description: While the Mt Ventoux was delicious, my 5 star rating is for the Club sandwich. It was absolutely amazing! Unlike any other Club I've tasted. Since it was my husband's sandwich, I had to restrain myself from stealing it off his plate.
author: Nichole R.

description:
arguably the best cappucino in town. though a it could be about $.50 less. 
love the baristas (mostly) and the vibe is pretty chill.
author: Denise R.

description:
Edit:  This place got me through the bar exam.  The staff was super nice, particularly as I became a regular.  The regulars were really nice.  People sitting alone offer up tables to bigger parties, out of sheer niceness.  Their sandwiches are in fact quite tasty.  And their banana pancakes are just awesome.  This place is too close, too pleasant, and too calming an atmosphere to get anything less than 5 stars.  Also the music selection is pleasantly familiar without being either too Starbucks or too out there indie.  I enjoy hearing Graceland every once in a while, and if you follow that up with somewhat obscure They Might Be Giants, who am I to judge?  The last day before the bar, there was almost a sing-along to Jens Lekman.  

------

I moved to my new neighborhood about 2 weeks ago, and, unsure of what was nearby, used yelp to find a good cafe.  I read over the reviews- I almost feel like this makes your experience kind of meta, because you're like "Omg, are the people at the counter going to be all hip and mean to me?  Is the coffee not going to be as fresh as [insert higher reviewed place here]?"  

So, I hesitantly decided to give Velo Rouge a try, because a lot of people did seem to enjoy them.  Truth is, I really didn't get any attitude from any of the people working there.  I would be the first to say that I don't look particularly hip- I vacillate between attempting to be preppy business casual and frumpy don't care (the latter being more of my look while studying for the bar exam).  So yeah, the staff isn't sugary sweet, but that's fine... I like getting my coffee and sitting down and working for a while.  I didn't feel judged, and I can be pretty sensitive sometimes.  

The coffee is tasty and they make a heart in the foam top of your mocha if you get it "for here."   The peppermint/rose tea is also AMAZING.  I mean, I know they didn't make the tea itself, but they decided to serve it.

I haven't eaten here yet, but given its proximity to me and several of my bus stops, I have a feeling I will fairly soon.  Also, during the week, it doesn't seem to be that crowded, but when it is, it's a lot of fun neighborhood people, including lots of cute babies and little kids (I have in my headphones, so noise isn't an issue).  So that's a plus or minus depending on your taste of clientele.   And they didn't kick me and my Barbri books out, despite me staying for 3-4 hours.

So why 4 stars?  It closes at 3 pm on Monday and Tuesday, but 10 pm the rest of the week.  Considering I have bar review until 1 pm, that means Mondays and Tuesdays are pretty much out for studying there (or grabbing a nice cup of coffee to take home).   That would normally be a half star deduction, so the other half star is for them not displaying any sort of sign about when they stop serving lunch.  I saw someone order a sandwich, and 5 minutes later tried to order one.  I guess it was 3:57 and 4:02 respectively, and they close the kitchen at 4?  Whatever, I mostly was bored and didn't really want to eat anyhow.  I got tasty tea instead.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I love this place, and sadly, after my cousins moved out of the area, I haven't returned. It's a great addition to an otherwise boring neighborhood/area in San Francisco. Its a cozy, quaint little place w/ good coffee, good eats, and fat tire on tap. A delicious and fun thing to try here is their South African Savory Pies-- they're like Piroshkis but better.  
My routine was grabbing a lox bagel on sunday mornings- simple but delicious. Oh, how I miss Velo Rouge. And although I've never tried any of their prixe fixe dinners (they would bring in chefs from all over for small candle light meals), but it looked really good. 

Give Velo Rouge a try!
author: Navid N.

description:
My favorite cafe in San Francisco. They serve Blue Bottle coffee, - one cup at a time - serve Fat Tire Ale and Pilsener Urquell on tap, and have good food items. 

They have a great atmosphere to just enjoy your coffee or beer or whatever you are having - free WiFi is also pretty sweet. They also feature Radio Africa twice a week (I think it's twice). Radio Africa, as far as I understand it (I haven't gone yet, though I hope to soon), consists of a prix fixe, meal that can vary, but has African, Californian and Meditteranean influences.

This cafe isn't far from Golden Gate Park, so it's a great place to hang out after checking out the park.
author: Gary B.

description:
Yup...they use Blue Bottle coffee beans...sigh...smooth caffine....
Never had a disappointing cup of coffee here.

However... on buzy period on weekdays and most weekend...The wait is apalling. Several times they were so behind... it took 15-20 min from entering the door to bringing out the coffee to the car. This happenend several times. The ride bar me from picking up coffee from here after several long waiting incidents!

They need to find a new system that when u are able to put an order early...get the drip coffee working so it will be ready when u reached the counter.

They have a full kitchen in the back! For a coffee house...they have a exiting out of the boring lineup in sandwiches and other menu items. For slightly over $12 have gourmet pizza, in which you could customize your own toppings! YUP...the pizza is a bargain and the quality! They had improved the dough. It is less doughy and have a nice sweet taste to it now. I will post a pic of the pizza soon.

All they need is to place more electrical outlet to accomadate  more wifi users in the evenings. It gets pretty dead in the evening, because of the isolated location. They are already crowded during the day.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
This coffee shop (Blue Bottle served) has a comfortable atmosphere, on a nice stretch of Arguello just a stone's throw from the park.

Seating is ample and comfortable, and in addition to the coffee they have two beers on tap and a selection in bottles.

Head's up that there's a credit card minimum that a single cup of coffee and a snack won't get you over.
author: Joel P.

description: It has now been a weekly weekend endeavor that I get my Velo Rouge breakfast burrito fix every Saturday morning. It is sooo big and full of flavor! It's basically everything you can ever want for in a breakfast wrapped in a toasted tortilla with a side of tortilla chips and what seems like homemade salsa. I'm currently scarfing down a burrito right now and can see eggs, cheese, black beans, potatoes, onions, salsa, and avocado. Sometimes the wait is a bit long, but it's definitely worth it. Can't wait for next week!
author: Ronald T.

description:
The Red Bike Rocks!

Kick-ass java in the AM, solid lunchtime menu, great lattes and other little goodies. Nice north-facing outdoor seating for sunny days. Owner Meg is the grooviest and lives in the 'hood-she'll make you feel right at home.

Check out Radio Africa & Kitchen there on Thurs nights, awesome food from fresh, locally grown, organic ingredients.
author: Dean L.

description:
Velo Rouge is such a refreshing change from most of the cafes in the area. For starters, it embraces cleanliness instead of the dirty grunge underground theme most places in the area go for. Moreover, it's a great place for cyclists who want to chat with friends over an espresso before hitting the road. I've even met the owner, a friendly, approachable woman who knows her regulars by name. 

I only have two issues with Velo Rouge, and unfortunately, they're important enough for me to take a star away from each of them. First, the quality of the coffee and espresso is poor. I'm afraid even the grungy underground places user better quality espresso beans. My second issue is the price. While I do understand that this is a trendy place, the decor alone is not reason enough to charge so much for their drinks and food. I might go again sometime, but only to take advantage of the social atmosphere and free internet.
author: Michael A.

description:
Great neighborhood cafe-- Good Service, Free Wifi, Good Coffee (blue bottle coffee-- if that means anything to you), Good sandwiches.... Live music &amp; Beer at night (or in the morning/afternoon if you please...).  Pretty spiffy place to hang out if you're in the neighborhood.

Only 1 complaint, sporadic cafe hours-- I would love to come here during the beginning of the week, but it closes really early (like 3p!!-- srly?!  3p?!)... Otherwise 5-stars.

I seriously would like to hang out here in the morning with a coffee and my laptop for work and loiter until late night with a beer... that would be such a great work day for this lil cafe rat :) ... oh one can dream....
author: kate y.

description:
They know how to make coffee and eggs or sure. I ordered an egg breakfast and a latte. The latte was excellent and as good or better than I have had anywhere in the world. The breakfast was really good. It came with what looked like homemade bread (two thick slices of sourdough). They have a strong bicycle theme going but then, with velo in their name, it would be disappointing if they didn't. Many nice photos from tour'de France. The ambience is relaxed, nice music but not loud, friendly people, some kids but not many. They also have free wireless internet which I have yet to try out. I will definitely go there again. I hope they continue to stay in business. 

I also wish they had longer hours. I know, I know, it's a local gal'n guy shop (mom'n pops don't seem to open cafes these days, or maybe they do in Florida), but they need to be as aggressive as the starbucks of this world if they want to stay in business.
author: Doble V.

description:
This is an awesome Breakfast/Lunch spot on a sunny day. It's on the same somewhat secluded block as Arguello Super, which is a huge plus. My staple here is the Pantani (Jack,Swiss,Cheddar, Tomato) Sandwich. It's probably my favorite sandwich in the city by far. All sandwiches come with salad. They also make a killer Moroccan Lentil Pie, which is unusual, but very tasty. If you like lentils/pulses, this will do it for you. They also serve Blue Bottle Coffee, which i haven't tried, but if that winds you up, then go right ahead. They have the whole french cycling theme going on (It's a great spot for Cyclists, Duh!), which is kinda weird, but the atmosphere is homely, and they have outdoor seating.

Swing by for lunch. You won't be disappointed. Props on the service.
author: Tushar V.

description:
I found this place on the way home from work and stopped in for a glass of wine. I noticed they had live music there and decided to talk to the owner about playing there myself. Meg is super sweet and she booked a gig for me and a friend. We played there just last week and looks are decieving- for its size, this place has wonderful acoustics (with the help of a sound system and tech-savvy employee), the crowd that filled the room was appreciative and attentive, and the atmosphere is warm and cozy when the sun goes down. 
I love this place!! I take my journal there to write, do work, and sometimes I grab a book off their shelf in the back to read a little. Very cool.
author: Robin G.

description: Excellent espresso, almost always!  Blue bottle is done well here and you can also find tasty treats from sweet things including yummy oat cakes and morning glory bread, mmm.  Comfortable atmosphere with indoor and outdoor options and often you can even find parking.
author: F. T.

description:
My favorite café in the neighborhood.  They've got some great food if you're able to snag a spot for lunch, especially hard on weekends... and they do have some beers on tap!  Nearly always busy, but the wait for a table's worth it with the great atmosphere and ridiculously friendly employees.  They are a music venue too, which is nice on some evenings to see kids rockin'.  Beware, they do close at 5 in the midweek.

As far as cafés go, I go the whole coffee-and-get-school-work-done route, and they serve Blue Bottle Coffee, which is divine as far as a cup of joe goes.  Mixture of tables and a few couches, with hip music playing.  Free wifi, yet plugs are sparse.
author: Cooper S.

description:
Mhmm! 
This is such a fab little place nestled in a dreary neighborhood. Im biased because I love all thing bicycle-oriented. They have a bicycle pump out front! 
Blue Bottle Coffee is supreme. Their food selection is unique and delish. Very friendly folks- cozy atmosphere. 
Check it out!
author: R J.

description: Suuuch a cute little cafe! Went there last night for the first time while viewing an apartment in the neighborhood. There were a mixture of people - some working, others eating dinner, and a couple others just enjoying a drink. My friend and I tried their Chai and Hot Chocolate, and both were delicious -- especially the hot coco. The food options also sounded delicious. I will certainly be back!!!
author: Michelle G.

description: Great theme and location for a Cafe!  Easy to get to and park/ lock up my bike.   I was on vacation and really looked forward to a cafe to enjoy a Large Latte, with my favorite flavoring, and WiFi for discovering SF.   A perfect trifecta of "No'" on all three ( No flavored Latte, No Large Latte, and No WiFi.  So a little disappointing...but again the location and the sandwich was perfect!
author: John M.

description:
So I'm really fucking picky about my lattes. I usually won't drink one unless I make it myself and even then, I won't make one unless it's on a decent espresso machine (ie NOT CAFE LA FLORE but that's another story). WHA-EVA I'm a barista, I do what I want. I however did want to see what all the hype about blue bottle was about so I stopped in to Velo Rouge (coincidentally during a bike ride) for a single latte. The barista (Jacob I think?) was really nice and the latte was perfect and totally exceeded my expectations. It was technically  the best latte I've ever had. I still can't say much about blue bottle because I haven't had any of the straight coffee or espresso but I look forward to going back and finding out what all the hype is about.

-Came here again with a friend and the girl who brought out our sandwiches was SUCH A BITCH. She threw them down onto the table and barked "I don't know which one is whose" and went back into the kitchen. Fine, I get it. It's a casual cafe and maybe I'm a bit biased because I essentially have her job at another cafe so I know how it's supposed to be done. You hover and say "ham and cheese?" and then the person that gestures that it's his gets the plate. Or if you're not in a chatty mood you just gently put the plates down. I'm sorry but you don't bark at people and slam. Ever. 

It's a shame because the rest of the staff was lovely and the sandwiches weren't bad and as I mentioned before the coffee is great but I'll probably never come back.
author: Nadia P.

description:
It was better when it first opened.  I used to get my coffee here almost everyday.  It was the best around.  Then they changed it and it's $2 for an 8 ounce and it's not always hot.

Before you could get a 16 ounce under $2 and it was the best around.

Food is good, but i stopped going here which means 1 star.
author: Jason C.

description:
I'll give them 3 stars based on music selection alone!

Any place rocking "Hotel Chelsea Nights" by Ryan Adams is the place for me.

They serve Blue Bottle Coffee and the Barista was a super-friendly, affable guy. I just came to read and hang out, but some other people ordered a pizza and beer and it looked pretty tasty; I'll definitely be back.

French for "the red bike" so bring your SFBC membership card and get 10% off everything.
author: Cole S.

description:
We found this lovely cafe by chance and it was a nice place to recover from our bike ride. 
Food and drinks were very fine. Nice idea to name the sandwiches after famous bike riders.
author: Florian E.

description: I had high expectations for this place. The French cycling themed decor is charming, to be sure.  But, that's the only good thing I can say.  The food was strictly mediocre.  The counter staff was pretentious and annoying -- blasting Hall&Oates while doing karaoke -- with little regard for those trying to eat.   The patrons were annoying combination of Haight Street zombie detritus and young families with children engaged in a i-can-scream-louder-than-you-can competition.   By the way, Blue Bottle coffee isn't *that* great.  It's fine, but, a little overrated.  Why does the Mission get all the good food?
author: Elliott B.

description:
They love dogs!

Very cute - saw the guy fill up a doggy bowl...I guess some of their repeat customers are ones that walk on all fours.  Since it's my first time here, I won't let the wait deter me from coming back.  The person taking my order appeared new - I understand being a novice, there's always a learning curve.  

Anyhow, onto the food!  My friend had their panini w/salad - it looked delish and since she killed the whole thing, I'm assuming she was satisfied.  I decided to go for one of their special and oh how i regretted it.  It was good, but I was turned off by their presentation.  My food (which was some kind of scramble with english muffins) was literally overflowing on a very small plate - one you'd use for your side of bread.  Anyways - didn't enjoy placing napkins as platemats so I could save my food.  

Overall I'd go again...maybe this time for coffee and a muffin...
author: Julie H.

description: Neat cafe!  Love the coffeehouse feel... But also love that it served more than just pastries.  To be honest, my meal was okay.  I got scrambled eggs, potatoes and toast.  Boring, but good... except the eggs were over cooked.  My husband got the veggy panini which was FABULOUS!!!  Sooo wish I would have gone with that. I didn't even finish my breakfast.  The coffee, however, was big, bold, chewy Blue Bottle Coffee, and it was yummy!!!!  :)
author: Lindsay C.

description: I live two blocks away and went for the first time today. Seeing that I pass it everyday, I though that I should give it a try. I went expecting it to be a good experience and was disappointed for a number of reasons. First, I waited in line for about five minutes. Then I sat at the only table available because the place is kind of small. I was sitting right next to the open front door and was cold. The place was extremely crowded at noon on a Wednesday. It was just too chaotic. I moved tables when I saw someone else get up and moved to a much better seat next to a window. However, the lady at the table next to me was breastfeeding and the baby was about one foot away from me. The food was ok.. just average and decent. The wifi internet worked for the first 30 minutes, but then stopped working and I couldn't use the internet at all. There was no network for Velo Rouge Cafe and no unprotected wireless signals available. The tables were kind of dirty and when I first sat down the last persons stuff had not been cleaned up. After a little while of not being able to use my laptop because of no internet, I gave up and walked home. Next time I will be trying a different cafe. I gave this place a try and don't think I will be going back. It wasn't terrible, but not enjoyable and overcrowded. Also, not one cute girl in the place.
author: Steve D.

description:
I used to frequent Velo often, in fact I've done the math and have spent over $1,000 there this year.

I've noticed over the past few months that there are many reasons why I will no longer support this business.

1) Convoluted Reward Program
They used to give a stamp for each coffee you buy. Now, if you buy 2 coffee's you get one stamp. If you buy 1 coffee, you get one stamp. To fill up the reward card, the math is below.

$140 for 20 coffee's = Free Coffee

$70 for 10 coffee's = Free Coffee

Does this make mathematical sense to you? They tried telling me that it wasn't fair for them to give a card punch for each coffee you buy. The short of it, don't buy coffee for friends or significant others, it doesn't help you. 


2) Wait Time
I've waiting up to 20 minutes for a latte and 30 min for a bagel with peanut butter on it, on a Wednesday morning, with no line and only 8 other patrons in the entire establishment. I've spent less time waiting in line at Blue Bottle at Mint Plaza on a Saturday morning with 30 people in line.


3) Poor Customer Service
For about 6 months straight, I went and bought 2 latte's every morning, every day. Never had an employee ask how I was, ask my name, remember my drink, or care to say a simple hello. The only nice person is the guy in the back who used to bring me my bagel. Pretentious 20-something age employees, you can leave your attitude at home.


4) Rudeness
I bought a breakfast sandwich at Arguello market because I was in a time crunch and couldn't wait the potential 30 minutes for a simple bagel from Velo. As we were waiting for our coffee's to go, my wife and I broke out our sandwich's to take a few bites before we were on our way. As I was putting a lid on my latte to head out, an employee came over to me and said that I couldn't eat outside food there and pointed to a non-existent sign saying so. Whatever, no problem I was leaving anyway. Without even letting me finish wiping up the spill from putting my lid on, he ran over to my wife and told her the same thing. If he gave me 20 seconds, I would have told her and we would have been on our way. 

The best part about it is that the barrista came from behind the counter as I was on my way out to post a sign saying "No outside food or drinks". So my wife and I were ostracized for doing what wasn't posted at the time. I'm not stupid, I saw you put up the sign after the fact.


FINALLY
Owners at Velo Rouge I say this to you: People look for good customer service in establishments that feel welcoming and comfortable. I can tell you that I'll take my $1,000+ to Cinderella and get Ritual coffee instead. You've lost a high paying customer. Oh and by the way, $140 for a free coffee? For the same price I could buy 4 Bags of Blue Bottle Coffee, a Bodum stovetop espresso maker, gallons and gallons of milk, a dozen bagels, a tub of peanut butter, a toaster and still be under 30 minutes.
author: Micah K.

description:
Velo Rouge top 5
5. Bike parking- makes life that much easier.
4. Mt. Ventoux- yummiest hangover croissant-which in all the land.
3. Outdoor seating- exciting because it is, unfortunately, rare in SF. 
2. Perhaps the friendliest staff I've encountered- they know my name and say hello.
1. Blue Bottle Espresso and Coffee!
author: emmie h.

description:
I am glad to see this little cafe doing very well in the Richmond. It's a sight for sore eyes - a great addition and one that seems to have longevity in its future! 

The Mt. Ventoux is delish! Simply fried fat with melted fat and crispy fat on a warm fat-ssant! It's comforting food and great with their chocolaty hot chocolate. Some of the best I have had!

The mere fact that it steals the show for cafes in that vicinity gives it a leg up. Unfortunately, I think the current staffing - generally friendly but slow to an aloof smile- sucks some energy from the cafe's good fortune.  I would give place 3.5 stars if I could.

.
author: Nancy C.

description:
For all you lovers of spicy, ginger cookies out there, desperately seeking to feed your insatiable desire for sweet, spicy, gingery goodness, to you I say:  Finally!  We have found the promised land!  I proclaim to you today, the Velo Rouge has the best spicy ginger cookie I have ever sunk my teeth into.  Rejoice one and all!  Rejoice!  

(Now, I just gotta somehow trick the owners of the cafe into giving me their secret recipe...  Then, I shall rule the world.)
author: Brian G.

description:
Stopped here for lunch during the middle of a 30 mile city loop ride.  I had the sandwich at the top of the menu.  It was very good, but the jelly on the bread i'm still not sure about.  good? interesting? not sure.  

Seemed like a really cool place though and if I lived in the area I'm sure I'd hit it up for good laptop times.
author: Levi B.

description: Great place to chill with friends or yourself. Good drinks with nice service. I like the atmosphere as people are either working on the laptops or just chatting with friends. Good little eats too.
author: Leon C.

description: obviously their coffee if phenomenal, its blue bottle.  The people who work here are always smiling even when its early.  Good mixture of people and great spot for quick and yummy eats
author: shannon h.

description:
I've only been to Velo Rouge once so far, but let me say that everything about my experience was wonderful!

The staff were super friendly, and the place is so cute inside. My meal was extra delicious--I had a panini that came with a side salad, and the salad was absolutely amazing. It was spring mix with sliced pear on top, but it also had goat cheese, blueberries, strawberries, blackberries, and corn! Pretty lavish for a "side salad".

My latte also didn't disappoint--everyone raves about Blue Bottle coffee for a reason!
author: Katie D.

description:
This cafe is really wonderful. The people are all nice and the food is excellent and well priced.

I've been here 4 times in the past 3 weeks (just moved into the neighborhood for the summer) and have loved everything I've tried. Their lattes are really good and they do the cute foam art thing, nice touch. Their granola with yogurt and fruit is delicious, as is the breakfast burrito, and the scramble with mushrooms and spinach on an english muffin (I forget what it's called). I've also been here for lunch and had the turkey sandwich panini with jam--also amazing. They served it with a very nice fresh salad with strawberries and other accouterments.

One drawback is that it's always crowded and there isn't a lot of seating, but that just goes to show how popular it is. I suggest getting your food to go and crossing the street to eat it in golden gate park.
author: Marrissa M.

description: Amazing pour-over blue bottle coffee, great food, pretty nice staff.
author: Travis L.

description: Came in cause I searched Yelp for breakfast burritos and this place came up. I wasn't disapointed! The burrito was hot, fresh, and pressed like a panini. Filled with beans, meat and other breakfasty delights. They served it with some chips but I also went in past noon so maybe the side is different in the AM. Sweet vibe with tons of cycling pictures on the wall.
author: Joseph F.

description:
I have been going to Velo Rogue for nearly 3 years and it is fantastic; I almost think they're worthy of 5-stars. I highly recommend heading that way if you're in the neighborhood.

5-Star Worthy
1. The coffee
2. Any of their sandwiches
3. The breakfast burrito
...and the fact you can get them all to-go.

Not-So-Worthy
1. Hard to find seating
2. Said seating is uncomfortable
3, A few, but not all, of the items seem overpriced
author: Andrea S.

description: I came here to hang out for a while today - what a great little place! The food was super good - I got a bagel with avocado and tomato, soy chai, and for lunch, a chick pea curry peasant pie. I was so happy with that, because it came with a little mixed green salad with all sorts of goodies - blueberries, strawberries, and snap peas, in a nice vinaigrette - what an unexpected surprise. I also had the brownie which was one of the best cafe brownies I've ever had - rich, dark chocolate with a little dusting of salt on top - just set the whole thing off. The soy chai lattes were great as well. They do turn internet off at lunch - a little bit of a bummer, but I totally understand why - they are a small cafe, and need to keep things moving. I tucked myself in a corner and tried to buy enough to eat to earn my keep! Staff were very pleasant, Modest Mouse in the background...all in all, I'm happy I found this place for today.
author: Karen M.

description:
This place is pretty good, relaxing and a nice place to sit outside and people watch, or maybe read a book. 
The one cup drip coffee method is a little interesting but good (its blue bottle i believe) but not a place that you are going to easily find a table for more than 2 people without a little luck. 
The park is only a few blocks away, the area pretty quiet, the people are pretty nice and its just a nice place to sit and read.
author: Tim K.

description: Now wonder I loved this white chocolate mocha.....I just discovered that they use BLUE BOTTLE coffee! hooray!
author: Lee M.

description: Always my favorite place in the Inner Richmond. Great people, amazing food. Serving bluebottle coffee & Cannonball wine what else can you ask for!?
author: Chad R.

description: I live across the street from this place. I can't say I've ever been treated badly the people who own/work there are cool let that be said. Getting even a bagel takes way too long. The space doesn't really work that well. It ALWAYS feels like somebody is sitting in my lap. If you're really into bicycling I suppose then you should check it out. And sometimes the music there is good but to be blunt it's not all that comfortable.
author: Steve P.

description:
VRC used to be Hang Chow Chinese restuarant back in the day.This is a nice little place in the neighborhood. If you plan to drive here, you better be careful because there is no parking available! If you double park, you risk the DPT on your ass because they are serious in this area. Your $3 cup of coffee may turn into a $50 fine or even more. 

They have a good sandwiches, bagels and such, but like many have said their service is really bad. It could be the lack of employees but it is not that hard to toast a bagel or slap some meat onto some bread and serve it with a cup of joe. This place is pretty diverse when it comes to the age ranges. You can find the 18 year old college students or the 60 year old retired real estate mogul. It has also turned very trendy recently because it is the "place" to be!
author: SF N.

description:
The four stars may be a little generous as I came here for brunch after having run just over 17 miles so - as you might imagine - I was pretty ravenous. 

They say that hunger is the best sauce, but in this case hunger AND syrup are the best sauces. I ordered the Jack Johnson Banana pancakes with almonds and syrup. While I was waiting for my food at the nice outside tables - owner(s) if you're reading this, the tables are fairly unstable and could be better positioned - I had a spicy ginger cookie to curb my appetite. It was a delicious cookie.

I washed it down with a few glasses of ice water from a large jug they had near the counter. I prefer this manner of watering customers to having to rely on an attentive waiter/waitress or nagging them constantly. There was also lemon in the water which I always enjoy.

The pancakes arrived shortly and were delicious. My only complaint was that there were only two of them and they weren't particularly large. For 7 dollars I'd expected a little more. Not a whole lot more, but a little more.

I'll definitely go there again.
author: Reed L.

description:
Oh, Velo Rouge...

You are two blocks from my door, have $3 Pilsner Urquell and Fat Tire for happy hour. Bagels with trimmings and all sorts of other delights. Plus free wifi. Oh and maybe coffee and tea too.

Neighborhood coffee shop win.
author: Taylor M.

description: Chill little cafe. Really friendly ambiance. Love the theme. Good for bringing a friend and chatting. Didn't seem all that conducive to working, but I'd give it another try, especially if I got a window-seat.
author: Dina G.

description: Breakfast Burrito is awful. Took 30 minutes to get a plain, non-toasted bagel.
author: Matt H.

description:
Places is awesome! I totally dig the bike theme.

-Great french press coffee
-Good Pancakes
-Staff is polite and happy
-Good place to meet people since you're kind of in a close environment

I noticed it can get kinda packed in here, so the seating isn't guaranteed when you walk in the door, but for the amount of space there is, it is plentiful.

I'd definitely go here again.
author: Kevin B.

description:
The bike cafe! It's so nice to walk into a cafe knowing they have great coffee (blue bottle) but most importantly they have great tea. 
It's not the easiest thing to find in the city unless you go specifically to a tea house. 
Seeing children and their parents also makes this a nice destination spot in our childless city. 
The food is great and they have super awesome organic eggs - a nice gluten-free protein rich option... mmmmm!
This is one of my faves in the whole wide world, for sure.
author: Laura A.

description: My friend raved about this place and told me to visit since I live so close to this coffee shop.  So, my husband surprised me and brought home a soy latte for me to try.  After a few sips, I was running to the restroom...I'm lactose intolerant.  My husband did specify to the guy behind the counter that I was HIGHLY allergic to dairy and all he told the 'barista' was to be sure to use steam(??)...isn't that how you make a latte anyway???  They didn't even bother to clean out the vessels or the equipment.  Not only did I suffer due to the coffee that was tainted with dairy, the small latte cost as much as a grande soy latte at Starbucks!   Never going there again...rather drive to Starbucks!!!
author: Alice C.

description:
One of the worse things a place can do to me is make me wonder if they forgot me... I go into this swirl of thoughts, making up excuses in my head for them... "maybe they ran out of milk and need to get more; maybe it takes a really long time to grind beans, and I'm unaware of the process... maybe... ugh, did they forget me?? do i need to confront them? am i just being impatient? Perhaps eye contact will give me a sign.. remind them??"  I don't know if I was just being impatient, but considering no one ordered after me, and it still took 15 plus minutes to get my drink while the dudes were chatting - well it sure made me feel like crap.  It was a great cappuccino, granted, but it almost felt like they wanted to watch me get anxious.  

It made me feel all the worse since they were quite friendly with other customers... you know, the pretty girl... the other hipster dude.  Sucks to feel like an invisible if not disdained customer for no particular reason.
author: beth b.

description: a great place to rest biking en route to golden gate bridge. down to earth menu with fresh local ingredients.. its a popular spot and seems always packed.
author: Jen L.

description: We're calling this place a 4.5, but rounding up. The minus half star is because my wifes breakfast was a tad cold. The fact that they served blue bottle coffee and Chimay at 9am more than makes up for it. My breakfast was wonderful with eggs and spinach and seasoned potatoes. The cherry on top was that they played perfect music for a morning in the city. Light baroque style choral music followed by the mezmerising cello of Zoe Keating. Definitely worth a return visit.
author: Cole B.

description: What a cute little neighborhood find. Outdoor seating for a sunny San Francisco Sunday afternoon. We brought a dog here and it was nice! They serve breakfast all day and have a plethora of sandwiches to choose from. We ordered the breakfast sandwich and coppa sandwich. They ran out of croissants which was a bummer but enjoyable nonetheless.
author: Jeanne C.

description: One of my favorite places to work + eat + and have a fantastic cappuccino (don't I sound fancy!). Also - great tuna melt and egg products.
author: Matt B.

description:
alright the coffee is good, but the prices are insane. it's $3.50 for a regular to-go latte and $3.95 for a vanilla latte. the prices are so expensive that they don't list them and the cashier even agreed with me that they are a bit pricey.

then to make the experience worse, i decided to get a stamp card and i only got one stamp even though i bought 2 drinks. when i asked about it, he said, it's only one stamp per day, but that if i wanted to come back later tonight, i could probably get another stamp...oh YAY? i read the stamp card later and it says in the top left "buy 10 coffees & the next one's on us!" THEN on the bottom right it says in small print "one stamp per person per visit." SO basically it's more like, "visit us 10 times and purchase at least one drink each time, then on the 11th visit, you will get one on us!"

2 stars for the awesome coffee.  velo rouge can't take credit for blue bottle coffee though....
author: Katherine F.

description: I'm pretty sure this is my favorite coffee shop in san francisco! I have to admit i don't drink coffee, but my husband does and he says its some of the best coffee he's ever had. I love that there is indoor and outdoor seating, and there is one small couch which i think is always great at a coffee shop. The food is awesome and the service is great. There is a bike rack right outside the coffee shop, which i love since i usually ride my bike there, and i can keep an eye on it from almost any seat in the cafe. The only downside to the cafe is that it's pretty small so it can be difficult to find a seat, at times.
author: myrtle m.

description: Good sandwiches - and they come with a big delicious salad full of fruits and veggies and feta cheese.  Their coffee is very good and the food usually comes out pretty quickly.  Not a five because sometimes seating is hard to come by, and their menu is a bit limited (though good for a coffee shop)
author: Sage S.

description: great neighbourhood joint.  everyone should go here for great coffee and support local cafes.  Delicious food too....  but the best is the coffee... nice and black. dont mess with it by adding cream and sugar.  Black is beautiful my friends.
author: Marcia B.

description: Great little cafe.  Good breakfast.  excellent coffee.  Nice atmosphere.  Great place to stop before heading over to Golden Gate Park.
author: Nedra D.

description: I have mixed feelings about this place. I came here on a Sunday, which was probably a bad idea because Sunday brunch is usually a pain. After wandering around the richmond and even trying to eat at the Presidio Cafe where they were apparently not seating anyone even with their empty tables, I remembered stumbling upon this cafe on a random yelp search so I wanted to try it. We came here and found parking pretty easily. But that was probably the only thing that was quick. We went in and ordered our food... it was a bit confusing, I felt like I was rushed into making a decision because the place is so small and there's a line. Craziness. After grabbing our number we went to search for a place to sit, which was a battle. There was no where to sit so we were standing for quite some time. I want to say 20ish minutes until a couple decided to leave. So we grabbed the table and waited some more. No one came to bus the tables even though some of the servers came out a few times to check on people and such. So our food finally came after A LONG WHILE, which wasn't making the day any better. When the food came out the server saw all the plates and asked if everything was ours... really? I mean I guess it's not impossible for people to order another round of food, but jeebus. So they finally cleared our table and served our food. Boy got the breakfast burrito and I got the huevos rancheros. My food was delicious!!! It was so good... idk if it was because I was starving or what, but it was really good. It kind of made up for all that trouble, so I wasn't as upset. From the tortillas to the fried egg to the sauteed bell peppers and sausage and cheese... OMG it made my tummy so happy :). The boy, however, did not enjoy his breakfast burrito. He said he had better from Jack in the Box. Ouch. I don't know how true that is because I did not try it and it could have been his irritated mood. I would come back here, but not on a weekend unless I take it to go or something. I have a feeling that is the average experience on a weekend. That place is not meant for a lot of people. So lesson learned.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Had a great breakfast here a couple weeks ago. Huge bowl of oatmeal with fruit that I actually ended up taking half of it home for later! Great food and drinks selection, and nice baristas.
The only down side was that so many of the tables had been commandeered by laptop users and they were only having a small coffee or tea, leaving most of the breakfast people to stand with their drinks and hope a table opened up before their orders were ready.
We managed to share a table with a girl who was "trying to finish a paper, so do you mind being quiet?" Um, yeah, we ignored her. When you sit at a table in a cafe there is an unspoken rule about sharing. I guess she didn't know the rule.
But it would be nice if there was some sort of mealtime rush rule that stated 'no laptops' or else 'no laptops at the tables'. Probably will never happen, but it would make Velo Rouge into a much better mealtime environment.
author: Rachel M.

description: This is my favorite cafe in San Francisco.  First they have excellent coffee.  It is either French press or individual drip coffee.  The food is inexpensive and really good.  The seats by the window hold my butt just right.  They are bicycle friendly to the max.  All of there menu items are bike themed.  In fact they are bike themed for bike geeks like the Mont Ventoux burrito.  If this place ever comes up for sale I am buying it.
author: Andrew C.

description: I love this place! I recently moved to the neighborhood to start grad school at USF. Their coffees and teas are great and their breakfast food is PHENOMENAL! I am obsessed with breakfast, so trust me. My favorites are the breakfast burrito and the huevos rancheros. The latter is only available on weekends, but is well worth it. I've had their paninis and those are yum as well. This is a great place to come with friends or by yourself to study (although I normally find myself doing more people watching than studying). Or you can just swing in and get a coffee and some banana bread to go. I highly recommend Velo Rouge Cafe!
author: Amy A.

description:
Velo is as good as it gets for a neighborhood coffee shop and cafe. Great Blue Bottle coffee (with slop drip or French press, if you want it), good breakfast -- oatmeal with berries is great, and are the breakfast sandwiches. Grilled lunch sandwiches with salad are very tasty, and sometimes live music livens things up.

Owners and workers are super nice...go here instead of Starbucks or other generic coffee shop.
author: Chris M.

description:
Time spent browsing GQ, stopping to look up any words I don't know (sort of an info-obsessed habit of mine) - 45min.

Time spent finishing a heaping bowl of granola, yogurt and fruit - 46min.

That, my fellow yelpers, is a yogurt parfait worthy of five stars by itself. When you consider Velo Rouge also offers Blue Bottle coffee, friendly service, free wifi, a nice neighborhood buzz/vibe and a pretty good turkey sandwich topped with spinach and jam, well, the whole experience becomes five stars. Great spot.
author: Jason B.

description: Hard to find seating at times, but thats part of the charm. The Mochas... oh god, the mochas... they are so good. The McAllister scramble is the dish I am eternally chained to, I always try but never seem to be able to get anything else because of how good it is. I've been frequenting this cafe for the past four years though so I have tried the Oatmeal, their daily soups, (my boyfriend is a HUGE fan of the BALT [Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, and Tomato]), the Arguello breakfast is good but nothing special, and the Mount Vontoux. Best breakfast sandwich I've found yet.
author: Emily M.

description: New to the neighborhood and thrilled to find  that this is within walking distance. Came in yesterday, and although the place was very busy, lines usually mean there's something worth waiting for, and I was not disappointed. The woman behind the counter was extremely knowledgeable about the coffee, and it was the best latte ive had, with a neat heart in the milk. can't wait to come back
author: Dana W.

description:
Best coffee drinks in the city, so I'm lucky to live a hungover-stumble's distance from their front door. On most Sundays I order the Breakfast burrito, and go there every day I can afford the time to get something delicious before work. I'd go everyday if I wasn't perpetually running late, since I need about 10 minutes to get my drink. And of course all the kids that work there are super nice. 

If I didn't live so close, I bet I'd be pretty stoked on the bike pump and parking too.
author: Melissa L.

description: I've only been here midday during the week, so I've never been there when music was playing. I could see a space issue on a weekend.  It had a laid-back atmosphere, and the collection of magazines was intriguing. My sandwich was very satisfying, and I'm not picky enough about my coffee to judge well.
author: Marcus M.

description: Velo rouge has it all- cozy environment, delicious food, and super friendly staff. I am a huge fan of the amazing salads that come with every sandwich- absolutely mouthwatering- strawberries, feta, corn, cucumbers and mixed greens with a tangy vinaigrette. Downside is that it gets pretty crowded during the lunch hours, but you can always share a table. Food comes out really quickly too, so it's great if you're in a rush.
author: Robin L.

description: Other than Cafe Grecco or Cafe Trieste, this place has the best espresso/cappuccino in the city.
author: Melanie M.

description: Just discovered this place, and wish I would have known about it sooner.    Nice little spot for coffee (they serve Blue bottle) and a good meal.  I wasn't expecting much as I tend to find that places that serve good coffee generally have just mediocre food.  I was really impressed! I ordered the breakfast burrito which had a good balance of eggs, potatoes, black beans, avocado, and some yummy cheese (it didn't mention what kind).  My only complaint was that it came with a side of nothing-to-rave-about corn chips and bland/mild salsa.  The woman next to me had a delicious looking sandwich, which she said was the veggie and also her favorite.  Cozy little cafe with an interesting decor (vintage French posters), great coffee and pretty damn good food.  I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Devin W.

description: Good food, great coffee, and diligent wait staff.  Definitely come here if you're looking for a good breakfast or even just a great cup of coffee to wake you up in the morning.  The place does get busy so it might be a fight for seating but I think the small wait is worth it.
author: Jackie C.

description: I don't know how they do it, but they pour the perfect cup of coffee. It's Blue Bottle, but no matter how hard we try we cannot duplicate it at home. Cool, laid back, friendly staff. Two mornings ago one of the many beautiful young ladies working followed us out to my car with a surprise free hot chocolate for my 4 yr old little girl. How sweet is that?
author: Malia D.

description: Velo Rouge Cafe is a cute corner coffee shop with decent seating and free wifi that brews up Blue Bottle coffee, and they have little sea creature finger puppets to play with while you wait for your coffee. They have Connect Four also, which you could probably play while wearing the squid finger puppet on your middle finger. They also have organic snacks and Battleship, not that one has anything to do with the other. On this lovely morning a certain someone said they would sink my battleship and that has absolutely nothing to do with anything.
author: Drue C.

description: I was very pleased to find out they serve blue bottle coffee as well as take credit cards. Great basic breakfast. The food runner did not want to bring me extra napkins or salt and pepper but he was more than happy to let me know where I could obtain them. Perfect place if you have a dog or enjoy the pleasant outdoor seating.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The cafe is really cute on a corner with convenience parking for your bikes.  The staff is incredibly sweet and they have Blue Bottle Coffee!
