I tried their breakfast which was the scrambled eggs with spinach and onions on an English muffin, it was average.  The ambiance was good, sat outside on a nice warm morning.
author: Carmen C.

description: Obviously the draw here is the cute factor. It's kind of a Moulin Rouge with Bicycles theme, and for the most part it's working. Predictable cafe food and decent coffee, but totally lovable because it's exactly what this neighborhood needs in that space. If this had been here when I was at USF, I would have been there all the time.
author: Megan W.

description:
My sister was visiting me from out of town, and is a coffee FIEND, so we walked here one morning. She had a regular coffee and I had an iced latte and both were very good. The service was polite and quick. We saw some of the other patrons eating various breakfasts and decided to return the following day for breakfast. I had the breakfast burrito, which was probably the best I've ever had. She had oatmeal, which was also delicious and topped with lots of fresh fruit. The portions were HUGE. When I got an iced vanilla latte the second time, the guy forgot to put vanilla in it, but that was an easy fix. The only reason I am giving it 4 stars is because it's really hard to find somewhere to sit. It's really popular, but a lot of people are working on their laptops too. They have signs telling those people they need to share their tables though.

I would highly recommend this place.
author: Cait M.

description:
This place only gets two stars because it was superclose to where I used to live and, fortunately for them, there are no other close cafes in the area. 

I went in here to get a small cup of coffee and plain toasted bagel with hummus for my boyfriend one morning. Someone tell me why it took 25 minutes for this to happen? As each minute ticked by, I was getting more and more upset since they were essentially taking time away from me being able to spend a few minutes in the morning with him before he went to work. After 20 minutes, I really wanted to go into the kitchen, toast the damn bagel myself, spread some hummus on it, pour coffee into a cup and bolt out of there. But OF COURSE there were only two staff members working a busy Saturday morning, who were both taking orders, no one was working the kitchen, there was a line going out the door and each customer had to tell their life story to the only two working staff members. Oh god, someone point me to a Starbucks where I'd get my custom made-to-order coffee and toasted bagel with cream cheese in 4 1/2 minutes. Don't get me wrong: I appreciate the quaint, cute little independent coffee shops for all their charm and avoid the big bad chains whenever possible. I just think they need to hurry the hell up and realize that making people wait forever is not good business.
author: Christine Y.

description: A very charming cafe that also hosts (mid-week) a prix fixe tasting menu from Radio Africa (self-described as a nomadic kitchen).   See my separate, and immediately following, review of our dinner, which was inventive and quite good.  But just as a cafe, Velo Rouge is, as I said, very charming.  The owner has heart, not just because she donated her night's profits to my friend's very worthy project in Ethiopia (see the Radio Africa review), but also because she just has heart.   I'm increasingly of Gary Danko's school.  If not heart (or love), then the food is eh to bleh and worse.  Here, there's heart.
author: Laurel B.

description: Velo Rouge is a cute corner cafe with--what else?--a red bicycle protruding from the front above the door.  Unfortunately, the coffee was a little thin and watery, though to their credit, they served drip coffee, not urn coffee a la Starbucks (yes, I take a jab at Starbucks in every coffee house review).  My croissant was kind of dry, though it was probably about 11 when I had it, so that's not entirely VR's fault.  Relative to SF coffee, I would only give Velo Rouge 3 stars, but relative to all coffee I've had, I'll give it 4.
author: Elaine M.

description: This place is a great small homey cafe with pretty decent food for those who love coffee.  They sell blue bottle and I like to take my coffee black.  It's great that it is cup by cup to order.  It makes me happy to know that they have a great bike rack outside and is located just a smidgen north of Golden Gate Park.  Free Wi-fi, some nice outlets, evening music really help the ambiance.
author: Kelvin C.

description: Great little spot for locals, particularly  USF students. Very comfortable environment for working or socializing. The outdoor sitting area is great on beautiful days for enjoying brunch. I highly recommend chai lattes and breakfast burritos.
author: Kayleigh M.

description: Aw c'mon.  Bike soul + coffee, located on a major bike thoroughfare on the way to/from GG Park?  It's a shoo-in by my standards, right?  I love the atmosphere here and the coffee is indeed very good.  And in July, you can spend your mornings watchin Le Tour on Le Television here.  But heaven help you if you're an impatient soul -- they sure like to take their time here.  Yes, slllloooow service: so you best be in the company of engaging friends or engaging book, else you'll probably go mad.
author: Alfonso E.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee, red wine, vegan soups, menu items named after bicycle greats and live music=one of my favorite cafes in town to both play music and pit-stop at on the way to Golden Gate Park. The barista/cook/sound man is gracious and attentive to his musical guests adn will even make a recording of the performance. If I lived closer, I'd be a regular.
author: Deborah C.

description: Passed Velo Rouge kazillions of times, always taking note of it. Finally went in and found one of the best kept secrets in the city. This jewel of the Inner Rich' has it all: great coffee, uber friendly service,  green conscious, free WiFi, comfortable environment hovering somewhere between neighborhood and casual student life, modern interior, Belgian ale...RRRRRRR!! (insert record scratch), "play it again Sam"... Yes, Chimay keepin' cold for Daddy! Modest dinner is served Wednesday-Friday. Charming little neighborhood gem.
author: Johnny C.

description: Super cute coffee shop.  They have weekend brunch too (the Jack Johnson Banana Pancakes look great).  Also, they serve breakfast until 2:30 p.m., and they have lunch after 10:30.  They have items such as salads, soups, and sandwiches.  Also, FREE wifi.  I came here with my girlfriend, yelped (actually I am here right now), and drank a Pacifico.  They do have beer and wine.  Plus, the atmosphere is super cute.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Oh, Velo Rouge ... how I could nitpick about you.  Your menu changed more times than I can count (where are the hash browns???), your super nice Sri Lankan chef moved on to greener pastures, your staff took for-freaking-ever to learn my name even though I was one of your first regulars.  And you're still damn slow when all I want is a blended coffee beverage.  sigh.  

Yet, I keep coming back to you for all my caffeine and egg breakfast needs.  You filled the missing coffeeshop hole in my Inner Richmond existence, and for that, 4 stars for you.

UPDATE:  OK.  The new year brings me a french press, motivation, and zero patience for the Velo Rouge Cafe.  They shut down over the winter holidays in order to "remodel" (aka move some furniture around and pretend like they've made the space more useful) and "improve service" (aka keep things exactly the same, i.e. unacceptably slow).  There is a simple solution to your problem, VRC -- ***make a separate drinks line, especially for people who only want drip coffee!!!!!*** (except now that they're serving blue bottle, even drip coffee is slower than ever).  

My other pet peeve about this place -- sometimes the reason the line takes so long is because the owner flirts and chit chats away with her favorite customers.  This annoys me to no end, because as previously stated, I was one of the first regulars yet receive zero preferential treatment.  I am lucky to get a "how are you" whereas some of the other customers get hugs, pet names, etc.  Like me, don't like me, whatever  -- just gimme my damn coffee on time and don't waste my time while you have small talk with the person in front of me for 10 minutes.
author: pitter k.

description: Great music, great coffee and a friendly chill vibe first thing the am. Another favorite coffee bar stumbling distance from a friends house. They serve Blue bottle coffee and have yummy beer on tap. Live music Friday and Sunday nights and Radio Africa & Kitchen sit down dinners Wednesday and Thursday.
author: Sirima S.

description: I love this place. Went there for a friend's wedding celebration. The staff is super nice and hard working, and I love the bike theme of the place. Great food. I wish lived closer, I'd surely be a regular.
author: Matt B.

description:
I just went here for brunch & I wanted a basic, eggs, meat with my fiance yesterday morning (my request was just  to him ravenously as we were walking to the car,  "I want MEAT NOW...protein, please" .... I'm preggars right now & he's sucha' good man, he doesn't question, he just goes & hunts & finds a spot esp. when I'm hungry...baha!) Anyway, we were conveniently parked right next to this cute, red cafe when we finished doing our Sunday morning errands -- so, he walks in & from the window -- he's just like "Get in here NOW b/c they have MEAT!"  Baha!...the ambiance is very European ...the patronage & people behind the bar are all shiny, happy, people...everyone has that Sunday puttering vibe in there & I love it...my honey had some salmon lox --  lots of lox & even though, he kept asking the wait staff for more jelly or condiments they did so with a nice, cheery demeanor for a relatively early Sunday morning...
Cool, I found a new spot to eat brunch nearby in the 'hood :)  Also, the theme as everyone mentions is a bicycle one & you can see it all around the cafe, the funnest part is actually seeing some hard core  racers sportin' their "Lance Armstrong" outfits on drinking their cuppa' joes & spotta' teas all the while their serious professional tour bikes are parked admist the red painted coiled shape bike stand...again, lots of atmosphere ...go if you want to put a warm, fuzzy feeling in your tummy & heart...
author: Elle F.

description:
LIKES:
1.  Mom & Pop Shop feel
2.  The food tastes good

DISLIKES:
1.  The wait is always really long in the morning
2.  I believe my chai was like $4.50.  And the cup was tiny.  
3.  They take so long to make the food that I am always done with my chai 10 minutes before the food comes out.
4.  The food tastes good, but you hardly get any of it.  My breakfast consisted of an english muffin with one scambled egg and some spinach and mushroom mixed in as well as a side of potatoes so small that it pained me to share one with my friend.  This teency breakfast and an equally teency cup of chai set me back $16!  
5.  I don't like the staff.  They are not friendly unless you catch them on an "off" day. 
6.  Not enough seating.
7.  Someone else mentioned it, but my #1 turn-off is the absurd number of patrons with babies.  There are at least 2 babies at each table and strollers all over the place.  This isn't Gymboree folks.  I would like to relax and enjoy my breakfast, but I can't because I must endure listening to a room full of whining, screaming babies throughout the ENTIRE time I am there, which will surely be at least an hour.

Before I wrote this I was thinking about stopping in again since I haven't been there in a while.  But after writing this list of Pros and Cons, I now remember why I stopped eating there to begin with.
author: Kandi K.

description: Cute little place with outdoor seating. Good for an inexpensive first date :)
author: Chris W.

description: Great coffee and great food. Not many cafes seem to be able to pull it off and get both right. This place is worth driving out of the way for. Very reasonable priced, too.
author: Kari J.

description: 5 Stars, despite the vegetarian/vegan options being precisely nil.  The staff is wonderful, they serve Blue Bottle coffee and it has that excellent blend of neighborhood feel and travel-worthy events that make you happy to live where you do.  The adequate bike parking, open bike pump and dishes of water everywhere to lure in puppies just seal my loyalty.
author: Jon B.

description:
Ok, I have to change my review on the velo Rouge. The irish owner is the coolest guy. He was really interested in finding out what a French kid was doing in his cafe working on a computer for hours. We talked for a while about biking and Europe. The next day, I came back to watch the Euro Cup and the caf was probably one of the funnest place to be that morning in the city.
I got to see lots of people getting their food and everything looks yummy, the Mt Ventoux breakfast, the waffles with strawberries... 
Futhermore, I saw the waiter helping a girl out cause she had a flat tire in front of the cafe, he let her borrow is race bike to go get a tube and then changed it for her, ok she was hot and maybe the guy would not have been this nice if the girl hadn't been this pretty, but still, he's a nice kid !
This place is awesome, if you like European sport : tennis, soccer, tour de france, you should come during one of those events...
author: Fred M.

description: Cool cafe on the edge of Golden Gate park. Met friends, one of whom is an espresso fanatic (see his rankings of the city's espressos: www.coffeeratings.com) so we were there to test out the product. Delicious cappuccino for me - nice crema although a bit darker than what I am used to. Cool atmosphere inside.
author: Mariangela S.

description: Dope!  this place just started serving *blue bottle coffee* last week!  I have a couple of friends who are regulars, and who brought me in for an afternoon coffee last Saturday to taste the blue bottle goodness.  I am stoked to have this delicious beverage available in my 'hood.  I loved the atmosphere, but my butt got kind of cold and sore, sitting on the hard metal chairs.... so maybe I'll have to reconsider spending coffee hour reading magazines next time, and get the coffee to go (to-go to my comfy couch, that is).  Now if I were to be able to nab the cozy red velour number in the corner, I'd probably stay there all day, staring out the window, sucking down the coffee, and calling my friends to come by and get a taste of the good life.
author: Laura T.

description: Velo Rouge Cafe is a great way to start your morning.  I had breakfast here for the first time recently and it was good.  I had the croissant sandwich with egg/bacon/cheese.  Not really hard to mess up, but tasted much better than I've ever made.  The GF had egg-white veggie scramble, because that's how she rolls.  She ate it all though and liked it.  The lunch menu looks equally good and I'm looking forward to trying those items too.
author: Rob U.

description:
This is more than the run-of the mill corner cafe.  The owners and employees of Velo Rouge clearly love both great coffee and great food because they will not give you anything else here.  The espresso reminded me of Italy, it was that good!  

The food can slightly pricy if you are expecting random cafe food, but trust me, as soon as you eat it, you will understand why they don't charge $5 for a sandwich.  

Sit outside on a sunny day and you are one happy cafe-goer!
author: Whitney T.

description: I. Just. Dont. Get. It.  I want to love Velo Rouge, I really do, however I cannot comprehend how it takes 15 minutes to serve a cup of coffee.  A cup of black coffee!!!  I guess you have to factor in the 5 minutes of blank staring from the barista after you place an order.  I have to admit that VRC does have delicious coffee which I was buying by the pound to speed up the process.  However, last weekend when I went in to purchase my coffee I was informed that they couldn't grind the beans for me (even though they have been doing it for the past year).  Ok.  Fine.  I wasn't upset by this until the manager informed me that I could buy their beans and go to safeway or my beloved Arguello Market to grind them.  No thanks.  You lost the sale.  I've never eaten here but the word on the street is the service is just as slow.  Shame.
author: Whatever Wanda W.

description: I have tried several times to like this place but I guess I am not hip enough  to get good service. The lattes are good if you can manage to get one that's not 1/2 foam but the attitude of the employees is a joke.
author: Elvis S.

description: This is such a great place to hunker down during a rainstorm if you are in the 'hood: beers on tap, a great selection of snacks and pastries, and a comfortable setting.  It's not often that I patron a place out of my town more than once and I keep finding myself in here.  That must tell you something!
author: Lauren L.

description:
definitely *the* neighborhood cafe, and one of my favorites.  meg, the owner, is so friendly and seems to always know everyone in there.

free wifi, great little menu of breakfast and sandwiches (recommend the mcallister and merckx)/special brunch features on the weekend, and a few months ago they started serving blue bottle coffee(!).  

and if that wasn't enough, they have quaint specialties like radio africa on wednesday and thursday nights ("a nomadic restaurant with sustainable products and methods" www.radioafricakitchen.com) , typically live music on friday nights and sunday afternoon, and just started featuring local director movie nights on the third monday of the month.  

agreed, the metal chairs are not the most comfortable, but hasn't held me back from spending a couple (or four) hours doing work there.

love this place.

[note: does take debit cards, but $10 minimum.  but if you become a regular, you can pay up front and keep a tab :)]
author: kristy g.

description: What a find! We spent a day walking all over the city, seeing the sights, but when the time came to get some lunch, we didn't want to go somewhere touristy, or to any place that tried too hard (e.g. we had to get away from the Haight). We were very lucky to stumble across the Velo Rouge; the guy working behind the counter was so friendly and zen-like (we frantic New Yorkers were trying to make up our minds about what to order in a matter of seconds, even though there was no one behind us, but the guy behind the counter just said, "Relax, no rush." To be that calm when confronted with neurotic East Coast types like us takes talent, I say!) The salads consisted of some of the freshest and tastiest produce I've had, and the sandwiches were tasty and creative. The atmosphere was funky and laid-back, definitely a neighborhood place. So glad to have strayed from the beaten path and found Velo Rouge!
author: Ari F.

description: Living by USF granted me few pleasures, but for the Velo Rouge Cafe.  Sunday morning brunch or just a saturday afternoon at the Velo Rouge was one of my favorite things to ever do. The staff is wonderfully friendly, local musicians play, dogs and babies accompany their owners, and the food is delicious and reasonably priced.  A great neighborhood joint and place to just chill.
author: Adam P.

description:
I really like this place.  The coffee is great, and although I don't drink fancy drinks like lattes and the like, they are so pretty I am almost tempted to start!  

As for the food, even a simple salad is taken to the limit of deliciousness with fresh fruit and feta...  and they have the best soups in town.

Go to the Velo Rouge, drink your beverage and savor the good life.  :)
author: Betsy D.

description: Really cute little cafe.....I saw my friend play here one afternoon and it was very nice. Nothing like sitting by a sunny window with a cup of tea listening to some great music :)  If it were closer, I'd be here a lot more often.
author: Barbs J.

description: It's hard to rate a place that I have only been to once and didn't eat anything, but Velo Rouge is pretty darn cool. The stuff was really nice when my mother and I stopped by for a quick drink after walking through Golden Gate Park for awhile. Oodles of options are available for food, and the croissant that I snacked on was pretty tasty. A good alternative to those "chain" coffee shops, it's safe to say I'll be back.
author: Victoria K.

description:
Cafe Velo Rouge serves blue bottle coffee, and they make it almost as good as in Hayes Valley (not quite .. but darn close).  The food is good too, although sometimes it does take a little while.

Why only 3 stars (at best)?  The people and general mismanagement.  

Here are some examples:
1. I hosted my wife's b-day party here in Sep 2007.  They did not have the wine as promised, instead only had a more expensive (not chilled, I may add) white.  When the final bill came, we paid $1300 for the wine, for only 30 people ... of which half had beer instead.  We got completely stitched and the girls running our private event were just awful.  We had to go get things ourselves from the kitchen.
2. The snotty behavior when ordering a coffee drives me bonkers.  I just asked if they had any pastries.  Answer: no.  Fact: they were serving croissants a volonte from the kitchen!!??  Seriously folks, I am not a fan of Starbucks, but you all ought to do an internship there and learn customer service volume 1.  
3. The music plays .. goes out .. the staff even doesn't notice.  It's eery  quiet here right now .. a perfect Halloween atmosphere :)
4. "Can I please have a knife to cut my croissant?".  Oh oh, wrong question!!  She sizes me up and shrugs.  I wait patiently.  After serving 2 more customers and realizing that I wasn't going to go away, she stomps to the kitchen to get me a knife.  THANK you so much.  Unbelievable nice.  Phew.
author: Philip I.

description: Stopped by after trying to find a place to eat around the park. It's very nice and quaint with reasonable prices. I liked that they served breakfast items all day, but tried out a small lentil pie and sweet potato soup. I cannot say I was disappointed, as it was all good, if not slightly small portions. The crispening of the cornbread was an excellent touch. A major disappointment was not getting the breakfast items (those were larger and looked really good) and any of the coffee (also looked really great and delicious). It did seem space is an issue, but you're a block away from the park.
author: Tony T.

description:
i had to walk several blocks in what felt like sub-zero temperature and came darn near close to crowd surfing on a packed bus to get to this place...but it was way worth it. the only real thing you need to know is that they make the most spectacular grilled cheese sandwich this side of reality (the indurian, if memory serves me). 

...also had my first hot chocolate of the season, which was delicious.

the atmosphere is cozy and the people are laid-back and friendly. i could have hung out here all night.
author: Mj S.

description:
turn down the f'in (live) music!!
the help seemed a little annoyed by their job.

decent sandwhich at a little table outside though.
author: Jeremi M.

description: I came here with Mike and Cyril and Mooch before the big race.
author: Patrick A.

description: I'd heard a lot of great things about this place and when a friend and I finally came here after a play date at Rossi playground, it was more than I'd expected.  Friendly wait staff with helpful suggestions, nice people sitting at the table nearby who were most considerate of our amped-up toddlers, and a great veggie panini on sourdough with a tasty, fresh side-salad which was more than worth the $7.50 I paid for it.  I will definitely be back again!
author: Susan L.

description: For a long time I could not figure out Velo Rouge's hours. But I loved it whenever I did catch it open. What I like most about this place are the sandwiches and the staff. I get the feeling that i could just plop myself down and stay as long as I want. I also find this Velo Rouge to be the best cafe (for a non coffee drinker) in walking distance to USF.
author: Nicole T.

description:
its just to dammed cute with that ole-fashioned red bicycle out front. 
great place to stoll over to grab a snack on a Sunday afternoon after lounging in the sun at the GG Park Conservatory
author: miss lisa k.

description: A nice little cafe to stop in after you've been bicycling around the park.  Kinda small, but they have Blue Bottle coffee, Chimay, and brunch-type food.
author: Asteridae A.

description: It is hands down the best cafe in the area.  Tiny and cute, they have the typical range of sandwiches, salads, coffees and tea.
author: Amme P.

description:
many in the neighborhood were psyched when velo rouge opened in a corner spot that had seen a series of always-empty asian restaurants. meg (who apparently has sold the place now, so things may have changed a bit) did everything first class, including blue bottle coffee. 

i go there every couple of weeks when i need a break from my office. they have free wifi, and the tables are often filled with laptops and usf students working.  and people with kids, always lots of people with kids. the outside seating is good for people with dogs, and there are water dishes for the pooches, as well as places to lock up bikes (which is the theme of the place... and on a sunny sunday, the bikers with their tight logo-strewn clothes and clunky riding shoes are everywhere).

it's expensive. if i get a latte (i always ask for the huge bowl cup they used to use) and a bowl of oatmeal (with raisins and nuts, yum) or a grilled sandwich (which comes with a fresh and tasty salad), i'm looking at 11 to 15 bucks plus tip. not cheap. and sometimes it takes foreever fo rthe food to come out, but if i'm working my laptop, the time goes pretty fast. and no one nags me if i'm still sitting there 90 minutes later, even if i haven't gotten another cup of coffee yet.

i've never experienced any snotty servers there, i have to say. in fact, the people who worked for meg were a lot like her, outgoing and smiling and truly neighborly. now i'll have to go down and check out what it's like now.
author: leslie a.

description:
bikes and coffee are the best dinamic duo for a chill out sunday.

this place has a nice bike rack outside and in/out sitting.
serves illy coffee and they also have shimay and fat tire beer in case of a hangover. double score. I tried their strawberry pancakes which seemed like a (pancake) version of a cliff bar, very yummy and healthy tasting with coffee. they have some odd hours but i been there mostly early (noon+) sundays. cute pictures of bikes.

*BEANS: illy and custom made coffee.
*BEANS UPDATE: Blue bottle.
*BIKERACK: loads and plenty outside (the cutest bright red bike rack in the city, I think...)
author: ninja M.

description: How friggen awesome! Theres a coffee shop that serves Blue Bottle Coffee only 3 blocks away from my house! On top of that it's authentic drip coffee. Worth the 4 stars because my girlfriend and I drank drip coffee, while playing classic board games such as Connect 4 and Battleship. My girlfriend kicked my ass in Connect 4, but I kicked her ass in Battleship. Good times.
author: Harry B.

description: This is a nice little cafe - their salads and spinach pies are quite good.  It's tough to go here for lunch though because it gets too crowded and there is no where to sit.  Folks have a tendency to hang out and hog tables for a bit longer then they should - or they need to add more seating somehow?  It's a small space though so there isn't much that can be done really.
author: J D.

description: I'm drawing to the close of my first year at USF. I'm from the midwest, so moving here involved a lot of culture shock and awkward beginnings. At the start, I really didn't know what to do with myself. I wanted to explore the city, but I didn't yet have a jump off point or ideas of where to go. More often than not, my mornings would start off at the VRC, where I got some comfort food breakfast, a smile, a cigarette and a coffee. It's a nice little dose of "good morning neighbor" in the morning. The staff are friendly, the food is greasy (maybe a little over priced) and good and the location is right off the park on Arguello. I'm glad VRC is around, and my thanks go out to it.
author: Jay C.

description: had a great turkey sandwich here today! the free salad was also great!
author: John E.

description: Velo Rouge is a nice place and sort of a neighborhood institution. I always run into neighbors there, and it has a nice vibe. To be honest, I'm growing tired of the food, but maybe that's my fault for always getting the same scrambled egg sandwich. It's a great place to drink a glass of wine out on the sidewalk on a rare sunny day. Sometimes they do awesome things like offer free pizza in the evening.
author: Aaron L.

description: I have been getting coming here for the last 2 years (mostly for coffee) and they never disappoint. The people who work here  are friendly, remember your regular drinks and how you like them. The food is simple and tasty. Its also a great spot to grab a beer and sit outside. They are usually fast even if there is a line and make your latte with care. Minus one star for regularly slow service from some of girls who are there in the morning.
author: Jessica H.

description: My first visit to San Francisco and one of my favorite places was Velo Rouge .... I've drank alot of coffee in my life but theirs is awesome - coffee and lattes ....very friendly people, opens early (yeah!), cool seating, the oatmeal and fresh fruit is great, smiling kids, dogs lounging outdoors (yes - a comfortable place) .... right outside GG park entrance - the owner should be very proud! A small but  happy place!
author: Susie H.

description: I love this place! Best breakfast burrito and they serve Blue Bottle. I usually sit outside because I walk my dog over here. I've never eaten lunch here but it looks great too. Seating can be difficult, but you can always get it to go and walk to the park to eat.
author: Carmen C.

description: Perfect place for sitting in the sun on one of the few weekends that makes me remember, oh yeah, I do live in California!  The food is fresh and colorful and the staff are nice. This is the most gigantic glass of wine I have ever seen, luckily I have all day...
author: R G.

description: As someone who lives nearby, I say Cafe Velo is very welcome in a neighborhood that needs community.  Drip coffee is good , altho take out coffee a bit short. Food is very good - grilled sandwiches , yes ! Try the Eddie Merckz.  Sometimes hard to find a place to sit and eat ... ask to share a table. After lunch go for a walk in the very nearby Golden Gate Park Oak Woodlands Natural Area just inside Arguello Gate.
author: Robert B.

description: So many many Saturday mornings i've stumbled bleary eyed and hungover into the kitchen to find my roommate not only finished the coffee but put the bag back into the freezer. At long last the inner richmond has  a place other than the reject safeway to get beans.  A great and very needed addition to the neighborhood.
author: Elektra D.

description: Let me preface this by saying that upon moving from Tender Knob to the Richmond, I lost all hope that I would find a decent latte in my neighborhood. I was so pleasantly suprised to discover this adorable cafe next to Golden Gate Park. I recommend the Merxx sandwich and the Belgian Waffle breakfast. Their latte is one of the best in town--good espresso with light, frothy foam. Yes, I'm a latte snob.
author: Jane R.

description: This is a great cafe.  My brother was singing/playing guitar here last night, so we stopped by for a couple of hours. I love the decor, with rouge walls covered with bicycle prints.  I had a couple of nice glasses of wine.   I can't really comment on the food, but the South African Savory Pies looked very tasty.  Nice neighborhood spot.  Very friendly staff, and comfy couch in the corner.
author: Stephanie R.

description: I would say the experience has lost a single star as a result of the new ownership, but I'm sure they'll get it right soon enough.
author: Morty P.

description: Best coffee in the area. Tastiest hummus, avocado & cucumber on a bagel. Good friends, good people, good place to hang out. And live music on Friday nights brings a little bit of life to the Inner Richmond.
author: Theresa T.

description: great little cafe serving up Blue Bottle and some decently priced sandwiches.
author: Regina C.

description: Cool place. Busy...sometimes hard to find a seat but good coffee and food!
author: Jack L.

description: Best lattes you can get without the Blue Bottle line.  The food is pretty yummy too.  I moved from this neighborhood over two years ago, but whenever I'm nearby I always see if I can get lucky with the parking.
author: S. B.

description: This is a cozy place to spend an Saturday afternoon to watch the bikes whiz by. As a fellow recreation rider, VRC has a warm place in my heart. They serve Blue Bottle Coffee and offers free wifi. One afternoon, I saw several USF students studying by the big windows. I do wish the new owners start implementing longer hours; I wouldn't mine hang out here in the evenings with friends.
author: Phillip T.

description: Velo Rouge Cafe is a small place with great drip coffee and awesome sandwiches! It's a nice location close to the park and petty mellow atmosphere. Prices are moderate, but definitely worth it.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
Good service
Good food
Good coffee

Only complaint is sparce seating. They need more tables outside for the nice days when all you want is to enjoy coffee and breakfast in the sun!
author: Annie L.

description: I love spending a Saturday or Sunday afternoon here. Good coffee, friendly staff and somehow I feel that every attractive person in the Richmond passes through here while I'm sipping my au lait.  Plus they have a bike pump outside for your bike.  Now if they only had a pump for both Presta and Schraeder valves, they would get 5 stars.
author: Kat W.

description:
this place is a wonderful little cafe. it has perfect ambiance....they have outdoor tables too, just a few...but that sunday morning breakfast was perfect out there.... their selection of beer is great too...nothing boring:)
customers and staff...wonderful
author: rachel F.

description: Great mocha, banana bread, service and atmosphere. They get 4 stars because half of their tables were occupied by laptop-ers with empty coffee cups at their sides. I hate coffee shops that don't kindly discourage such use of their space! We waited 10 minutes for a table; by then my coffee was cold and my mood was sour.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Usually the best coffee in the Richmond, however it lacks consistency, and the staff is not all that engaged.

For the best coffee in SF, try Ritual Roasters and Four Barrel in the Mission.
author: Mike G.

description: Velo Rouge is one of those super cool places you hope to find in a city like San Francisco.  The best thing it has going for it is the super tasty coffee. The food is decent but nothing to write home about. The next best thing is the feel of the place: bohemian with a European flair; the staff are friendly, the decor inviting and different,  and the customers reflective of the multi-ethnic city. Overall, it is a great place to relax.
author: teo p.

description: Awesome coffee, breakfast, and atmosphere. This is the best new cafe on this whole side of town in a long time. The belgian waffle is weekdays only, but is out of this world.  Never packed, always exceeds expectations. Also bike friendly. Near the park and on the way out or back from many a ride. Have an espresso and watch the Tour in July. Cool event too. Check it out.
author: Sarunus J.

description: Great little cafe in the Inner Richmond, especially for a pre-Presdio bike ride.  Friendly staff they even let me bring my Seven inside since I was afraid to leave it outside.  Cute T's too!
author: V T.

description: I've wanted to try this place for a long time, so as we casually drove back home from a social event, craving some nosh  and a coffee drink,  We finally paid a visit. The Mt . Vontu Sandwich (croissant, with eggs, bacon and cheese) was eggggscellent. It was so good, we had to order another (That and the kid gnawed most of mine away). We also enjoyed our cappuccinos (I had 2) very much. This is a bicycle-themed place, (that we drove to, tsk tsk.). Lots of Tour de France references on the menu for the bicycle crowd. (Funny thought, I most likely know more about Le Tour than most of the "b" crowd). The help was very friendly, and the line endless, but not too long, on a Sunday afternoon. Along with the various "french-like" sundries, they have a couple beers on tap. We left before the jazz band set up. Maybe we'll stick around longer on our next visit and I think I'll get the Leipheimer burrito
author: Rich M.

description: Great coffee, great tea, great sandwiches, and great service. Trendy-ass place. I love the whole bike scene. You have to check out the posters and pictures. Some of them are for sale.
author: Al A.

description: What a gem of a place!  After a pleasant visit to the DeYoung, I came per suggestion of a friend for an afternoon pick me up.  Their soy mocha and cappuccino definitely hit the spot, but I guess that's too be expected of a place with blue bottle service.  We paired this with a nice fruit bowl, which had surprisingly fresh fruit! (for once).  The mood is what you would find at your typical corner coffee joint in SF, though don't be fooled by the bikers who often come here in groups to hang out.  (It is, after all, called "velo rouge").  It is an eclectic mix of your typical SF yuppies (myself included) coming here for an afternoon coffee with their computers blogging about their experience, your average student in the corner studying for his GREs, the bikers carb-loading after a long ride, and your older crowd who come to read the daily paper and watch a game on the TV.  I'd definitely recommend to anyone.
author: Ben T.

description:
As a resident of the Inner Richmond I am rooting for this place to be a success but they are making it hard to be a supporter.  The food and atmosphere is fine almost great,  but the wait on a Saturday or Sunday morning, even when its not crowded, can be unbearable.  Someone needs to tell these folks how to run a restaurant.  Is it a business or a hobby?

Rule #1: always have the coffee cake ready
author: T R.

description: It should not talk 40 minutes to get a salad and sandwich.  The staff is stoned and incredible unhelpful.  2 people who were behind us in line were severed before us.  And the food was not worth the wait.  I am shocked they have survived on crappy service like that.
author: Amy P.

description: i always look forward to visiting my family in san francisco... because that means i get to go to velo rouge cafe!! it gets crowded on the weekends so beware but it's so worth it! the coffee drinks and the food are amazing! the mt. ventoux sandwich is my fav!!!
author: stacy w.

description: I love this place! Good coffee. Good cappuccino. Good breakfast. What more do you need. Only reason they don't get a 5th star is because of the coffee that is brewed in a press which just doesn't taste the same as the classic drip!
author: William N.

description: Warning; avoid this one place with lame owners/workers. The people who work there are so RUDE; this is the worst customer service I have had at a coffee venue. They served me stale,  terrible-tasting coffee. I had a just one sip and almost choked by how terrible it was. I regret not calling the health department. I was super nice to the person at the counter and asked her to exchange it with something else because the taste was weird. I did not make a big fuzz or anything. She replied that I had to drink it; they would not replace it and another guy came there, had a horrible thug-like attitude,  looked at me like I was a thief and began to imply I wanted to drink coffee for free (duh.. are  you kidding me dude??The whole cup was full!  Accept that your coffee can sometimes be just lame! If I want to drink free coffee I will go to Trader Joe's where the coffee won't kill you!!) So I threw away the whole cup of coffee in front of them. There are plenty of nice coffee shops in the city where the personnel treats you with dignity  and the coffee tastes good for anyone to consider this lame place.
author: Kyrsch K.

description: they serve blue bottle coffee here, woohoo.  the cafe is really cute, and they had a variety of breakfast dishes that are served late into the afternoon.  i came by here yesterday and just had coffee.  service was a bit slow here, but the place is nice for a neighborhood cafe.
author: Helen T.

description: This place is a perfect low-key, relaxed, and not too hipster/i'm not wearing tight enough jeans to be in this place- cafe. The people that work here are incredibly nice. They also serve blue bottle coffee, and this may be one of the cheapest places to purchase it in the city ($2). I work just up the street and go here for my lunch breaks. The food is great, especially their soup of the day. It's usually vegan and absolutely delicious. They have outdoor seating which is super nice and also have beer specials for happy hour. Great place to go with a friend or just to catch up on some reading. Very quiet and removed area and  just a block from Golden Gate Park!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I didn't expect this cute little cafe to be tucked into this mostly residential corner of inner Richmond.  As its name implies, the cafe has a French, red, bicycle theme.  The small room is comfortable and clean with outdoor as indoor furniture (mostly wrought iron tables/chairs with a small couch/coffee table in a corner).  There are a few outdoor tables and a red helical bike rack with the requisite red bike.
There's a full and diverse menu, which I haven't tried.  But the first time I visited, I had a bagel with egg and cheese.  Usually, a breakfast sandwich like this isn't worth writing about, but I was suitably impressed (fresh, toasted bagel; a real fried egg rather than the microwaved stuff out of a carton; good cheese).  I'm looking forward to get the chance to try other menu items.  Unfortunately (or maybe fortunately if you're a local and like it quiet) there aren't any supporting businesses next to the cafe -- I only see a laundromat and small market.  I just hope there's enough neighborhood and bike transit traffic to keep this great place going.
The only thing stopping me from giving it a full 5 stars is that I've been only a few times for tea and haven't had the coffee yet.  Too bad I don't live in the area anymore; thank goodness a friend lives nearby and I can stop in everytime I visit.
Happy 1-year anniversary!  Hope it'll be around for a long time.
author: Tom W.

description: I live right around the corner so I come to this tasty establishment often.  The staff is really cool and the food is good as well; However, I would say a tad bit expensive.  On weekends they have live music and the talent they bring fourth is really good.  In fact, just last night me and the girlfriend listened to this duo that sounded a lot like the Kings of Leon!  Anyhow, great place, good people, great music... what else do you want.
author: Patrick P.

description: Waaayyyyy overpriced.  $2 for a small (like the small Starbuck's size) coffee? I asked for a large coffee to go and that's what I got.  I am all for supporting local businesses (I still rent movies from stores...no Netflix for me), $2 for a small cup is pretty steep.  I can get one twice as big that costs less at Starbuck's or Peete's.  The food is also overpriced. $6 for a couple scrambled eggs and toast.
author: M G.

description: I recently visited Velo Rouge Cafe with a purpose of purchasing a coffee, perhaps a dessert and use their wireless internet (advertised in the window). I had a HORRIBLE experience. I rarely write reviews, but felt the need to write one for this place. First of all, if a cafe has internet for customers to use, it should be available ALL the time. I was there in the middle of the day and the RUDE baristas blatantly explained it was off because it was busy in the cafe. So basically, they wanted me to pay for my coffee, drink it and leave. I have worked in the restaurant industry for several years and it is common knowledge to be friendly to customers if you want them to return. This girl was flustered and very rude. It was 2:45pm and she told me it would be turned on at 3pm. Sure enough, I waited 20 minutes and even after the line dwindled down, the girl just stood there refusing to turn the internet access back on.I will never recommend this place to anyone or ever return. There are too many coffee shops in SF that are much more pleasant than this place, like Cafe Enchanted (where I am writing this review because of the free internet access).
author: loren h.

description: Great coffee, breakfast and bloody mary too...
author: Brett K.

description: We usually go to this place for coffee and breakfast. I like their Mt. Vernou (spelling?) and breakfast burritto...I think I've had their other breakfast items and they were all great. However I think it is a bit pricey but it's alright. I like the location and hip style of this cafe. We've never had any bad experiences coming to this cafe. The coffee is good but just watch out for the coffee grounds though (don't drink it b/c it's bad for you).
author: JM M.

description: delicious coffee.  really.  best in the 'hood.  (I live in the 'hood).  can be a little busy though, so not the best place to stop if you're in a hurry.
author: Venus H.

description: Best mochas ever!!  This is my favorite coffee shop ever!!  The staff is really friendly, and they make the best coffee.  They also have really good food as well.  Great place to hang out and study.
author: Jennifer M.

description: The couple times I've been to this cafe I've really enjoyed the experience. However, I came in the other day to get blue bottle coffee beans for a trip I was going on. The gentleman behind the counter very politely apologized for not having any and sent me to the nearest little organic grocery store that carried it. Just for that I'll make it a point to buy by blue bottle beans there.
author: Christine N.

description: Velo is the best place in the city to get a Blue Bottle individually dripped cup of coffee, and I also recommend their mocha that is mixed with Ghirardelli chocolate, which makes them extra creamy. The breakfast burrito is out of this world delicious! This cafe is all about the cyclist, and is decorated from head to toe with classic, old black and white photos of the Tour de France and other cycling races, along with other bike paraphernalia. Tons of bike parking out front. The cafe staff are warm and inviting.  The only draw back to this cute and cozy cafe, is that it is a bit too cozy on the weekends where you will stand in a line six people deep (it moves fast) and after you've made your order there are only seven small tables that fill up fast, so you may not have  place to sit. If only there was more space. Try to stop at this cafe during the week or for a quick in and out coffee, you won't be disappointed.
author: Valencia D.

description: Charming little place with great coffee.  Blue Bottle beans and yes, the baristas are trained coffee nerds who know what they are doing.  Love the "Lone Mountain" which is like a super condensed latte in a shot glass.  The music is usually good which makes it a cozy place to sit around for a while.
author: Matt B.

description: I agree with the last guy - staff is often rude, except for this one person who works some weekdays.  Food is mediocre, except for the bagels, which are good.  3 stars for serving okay coffee, good bagels, wireless internet, one nice employee, and good yogurt.
author: Laura A.

description: Well decorated, but not over-the-top.  Parking is easy, so it is a good place to meet.
author: Ben R.

description: great service, great pancakes, good lunch options, and radio africa on thursdays is great as well. plus they are all about the biking. i mean comon people this place is awesome and on a million bike routes!
author: lissy d.

description: Great place. They were smart to cater to bicyclist, especially since it is somewhat off the beaten path. Otherwise it is pretty standard for a caf.
author: Tedster H.

description: amazing sandwiches. i had the zucchini, red pepper sandwich and it was awesome. and the salad it comes with is super tasty with plenty of fresh fruit. drip coffee isn't bad either.
author: Matt R.
